I recently spend a beautiful day in The Mission and ended the evening at Gestalt Haus. Ashley M. and I first walked by this place on our way to the end of the block or somewhere, but the sign in the window advertising "Vegan Tuna Melt" told me I suddenly had other plans. We went inside and took a seat at the bar. My phone was dead by this time so I couldn't check in, but more importantly, I was not aware that it was past 6:00 p.m. They stop serving sandwiches after six. Thankfully, they also had vegan sausages. 

The vegan sausage was delicious. I loved that the bun was toasted. The toasted bun really sealed the deal for me. I ordered the sausage with sauerkraut and onions and tried the two different mustards and even some ketchup. I still want to try the "tuna" melt, but I would return just for another sausage.

Halfway through my sausage I ordered an Arrogant Bastard from their selection of bottled beers. It went nicely with the sausage. 

Ashley M. let me try her Downtown Brown. I liked the flavor and would recommend it if you haven't tried it before.

There was a weird dude trying to pick up on me which took a little bit away from the nice evening we were having. Oh well. The bar staff was very nice and attentive.

I'm looking forward to checking this place out again and trying the vegan tuna melt. 

"Sausage" count: 6
author: Daisy S.

description:
An okay place to drink with friends, especially bikers (and I don't mean of the motor variety). They have a double decker indoor bike rack which is both amusing and useful (now you can drink without worrying about your carbon fiber fixie). 

The crowd is very laid back and we talked to a bunch of random people, friendly folks all around. The theme is German, but they didn't seem to have a killer German beer selection, nor were there many Europeans hanging around. It's more of a Mission hipster scene.

Mostly dudes, so don't come here looking for a healthy pickup scene 'cause it's not going to happen. Better to bring your own sand to this beach...
author: Jeremy S.

description:
I did not plan on coming here, but I was across the street and (random fact) gestalt is one of my favorite words and frequent metaphors.  I think the word "gestalt" combines the affection I feel for both  existentialism and communism.  So that's why we came.    

They have beer and sausages, which is what you want from a Haus.  

Moreover, they seem upright and friendly here, and the "DJ" was playing a...oh, let's call it... eclectic (unstructured) mix that was enjoyable.  

I didn't get a sausage but I will, and that might earn them another star.  If Gestalt Haus proves it can out muscle the fascist, axis rule of Rosamunde & Toronado they will deserve a congressional medal of honor!
author: Luke M.

description:
I'm curious that I have never reviewed Gestalt Haus before tonight.  When it's not jam packed crowded this is one of the best little kept secret bars in the Mission.  Granted, it has the worst BATHROOM in the Mission (go across the street to Kilowatt if you have to go, tip courtesy of Mick F.)  That aside: the beer is plentiful and cheap; the sausage is bang on and the potato salad is worth going to Gestalt alone for.

Delish!

On crowded nights, only go if you really REALLY have a hankering for sausage with sauerkraut.

Another up side to Gestalt - at least for me - because they do not serve anything other than ale or wine it's damn near impossible to get stumbling drunk at this bar.  Which at the age of 35 is a good thing, because I've had too many hangovers in my life thus far and need no more... Gestalt lets me go be social without risk of being sloppy knee walkin' drunk.

Yay!  Win-win-win!
author: Kate R.

description:
If I lived in San Francisco I would come here regularly, as it is I stopped in here while waiting to met a friend coming in from Oakland on the BART at the nearby 16th and Mission stop.

Love: The bike racks on the wall, the righteous beer selection, the enthusiasm of the lonely DJ, the delicious taste of a Fat Tire, the non-pretentious clientele. 

For a bar randomly picked while walking up this street, this payed off excellently.
author: Michelle L.

description:
On our way to Elixir, we needed food.  "No Vietnamese," said my friend, "my Uncle went over there and came back funny."  I was feeling up for stout midwestern meat-and-potatoes fare, it being January and the state being subjected to abnormal "freezing" temperatures . . .

"Beer, brats, and Bikes" promised Gestalt.  We gave it a try.

Bikes?  They mean bicycles.  There's a double-decker rack by the door, and everyone in the place has a helmet, and often a front wheel, hanging out with them.

Beer? Alright . . . the bartender seems nice.

Brats?  Well, for $4.50 you get a mediocre brat drowned in sauerkraut.    On a bun.  The bun is nice.  But, see, when I see "beer" and "brats" paired on a sign, I'm thinking the brats have spent some time swimming in the beer.  This bratwurst was . . . underwhelming.

The decor is chalkboard black, with vertigo-inducing rows of Christmas lights on the ceiling.  I would NOT come here if I was tripping.  I would NOT come here, really, unless I had a thing for bicycle people.  This place just kind of creeps me out.  I would not come here, but to each their own.  It's hardly awful, certainly different, and if I were a bicycle nut, I might feel right-at-home.

NB: I was using the restroom and my colleague told the guy to bring on the kraut . . . stuff slides off, so no frets.
author: Danny H.

description: Wonderful draught and bottle list. Great for watching sports. You have to try the pretzel and nacho cheese! Great crew behind the bar.
author: Ryan K.

description:
This is a really cool bar...when there's not that much people. Instead of parking your precious bike along the busy 16th St., the bar provides a indoor bike- rack for your bike. They also serves specialty Bratwurst and other snacks. Some of their signature beverage is the liter-size imported beer for $10.00.  

No, Matt didn't left the alcohol closet, but settle with iced cold bottled-water for $1.00. It was desperately needed to extinguish Matt's thirsts with all the Yelpers around this heated bar.

When Matt mentioned, "When there's not that much people", recently a special event has been one exception. 

The lovely Yelper, Stephanie, has held her goodbye party here, before she heads off to Minnesota to pursue further in her education. Her goal is to obtain a BA Degree in Psychology. Maybe she can teach some of the immature yelpers a thing or two on how to act sophisticated like the silky-smooth Stephanie.

Matt stay was brief, but good enough to embrace and say good-bye to the lovely Stephanie. The hardest thing to do was to let her go, because Matt loves her to death like an immediate family. Matt did give her a gift thinking about Matt. 

The gift comprised a superhero, who wears Red, White and Blue. 

San Francisco and the entire Bay Area have lost, but Minnesota has gained a great Yelper in Stephanie. 

"Good Luck, Stephanie!"
author: Matt G.

description:
Maybe I hit this place on an off-night, because I really wanted to like it, but just wasn't feeling it. It has all the makings for a great place - relatively good beer selection, food to accompany, bike parking, a pool table and even pinball. But the vibe was way off. Too crowded, a bit pretentious (the bad kind of) and a DJ who was playing kind of lame music (and we were the only ones dancing but he still wouldn't play our requests). 

In the interest of fairness, I'll give this place another shot because I think it has a lot of potential to be awesome, but based on first impressions? Eh.
author: Natalye R.

description: Didn't like it except for the Pacman machine and beer selection. As soon as we walked in everyone knew we were out of towners! The bartender was rude to us. I get the whole local bar= local people, but really. No need to look at us all crazy when we walk in. Disliked
author: Christine M.

description: Not a bad selection of games (still prefer Brewcade) but love how much stuff they have on tap and especially love golden state mighty dry cider
author: Mia F.

description:
Came over here to watch the NCAA Final Four on Saturday afternoon. I originally headed to Monk's Kettle, which I've been wanting to hit up for a month, but was steered away by friends because they don't have TVs. Thus, using the Bill Clinton methodology, we took whatever was close to us and ended up at Gestalt Haus. 

This place does have 20 beers on tap, BUT they don't do pitchers. It's either $5 for a pint or $10 for 0.5L. Kind of expected this place to be cash only, but a part of me still hoped that they'd take credit card. Gestalt Haus is a great sports bar. They have a pool table in the front, but the winning element is their huge projection screen in the middle of the bar. With that, anyone can see, but if you're at the bar, then there are small TVs for you as well.

The beer selection is pretty legit, ranging from your normal beers to ones like Racer 5 and Drakes 1500. Aside from beer, they also do sell sausages like kielbasa, etc. I didn't try them because I was on a liquid diet, but they smelled good. If you're looking for a unique beer, they do have the double chocolate stout which was actually pretty decent.

With all bars, the downside is that this place does get packed. I'm going to say its because of the game, but still. I hate waiting 5 min just to get a beer. They have one bathroom but it's pretty grimey. Hipster-ish crowd, but I wouldn't expect anything less from this place being in the Mission.
author: Michael W.

description:
Stopped here while we were waiting for a table at the monks kettle. They have a
Pretty good list of tap beer here as well as a nice list of bottle. I ordered a twist of fate from moonlight which was good. 

The atmosphere was geared towards the hipster crowd with an indoor bike rack, pool tables, jukebox, and decor. It would probably be a good place to come hang out for a while, drink beer, and socialize. 

The only grip I had was it seemed they have an issue with fruit flies. It wasn't overwhelming... but it was noticeable with me having to just smash about 4-5 of them. 

Overall, the beer selection and atmosphere make this a spot you should at least have a beer at.
author: Anthony R.

description: Great sausages!  Great beer!  Thanks for the great food!  Next time I'll be sure to bring some coin to play pinball.  I'll definitely be back!
author: Randy A.

description:
Finally came here a few weeks back when my buddy Roscoe was in town for the Outside Lands weekend.

I guess I found myself a bit let down after all the great reviews I read. Sometimes, my inner interior decorator gets the better part of me and the little things that are a bit off start getting on my nerves. First, the stools are too short for the bar - you're just about drinking with your elbows at ear level. And then you got these animal skulls thrown haphazardly on a bare black wall which gives the impression that little thought was going on with the interior design. Finally, one bathroom to share with the girls and boys doesn't help the situation either.

I know these are little things and I'm sounding a bit whiny, but like I said, it adds up. Plus, throw in some odious youngsters that talk too loud and dance like Ellen Degeneres and you got an uncomfortable situation on your hands.

Unfortunately, I didn't try any sausages so perhaps the rating would go up after I finally try some. 

Having indoor bike parking doesn't necessarily make a bar cool either. But there wasn't anything that *really* turned me off so I'd definitely be down to give it another shot.
author: Art O.

description:
Dear West Coast Hipsters,
You know how to do it here. Unlike your eastern counterparts in Brooklyn, I can turn to a juke box and see music that I actually know and love, I can order an astounding variety of draft beers that come in the appropriate vessels, and the obscure movies you play on your television screens are actually interesting simply because they are footnotes of film history, not because they represent some sort of blase intellectual phenomenon. The music also wasn't too loud, which allowed for actual conversation. I didn't eat here, but your sandwich selection looked ravishing. Well done!
author: Mike O.

description:
I was going to give this place 4 stars, but i think it's totally deserving of 5.

I was hungry. I was so hungry on a wednesday night after 8 and not wanting to wait an hour for a table at Monk's Kettle. I was HUNGRY. My friend almost didn't want to go in, but he could see the look in my eye as i pulled off my best Oliver Twist "Please sir, can i have more gruel?" look.

The menu is not impressive by any stretch of the imagination, but it was a wholly satisfying menu. Sausage sandwiches for $5? Sold! I also thought the toasted sandwiches sounded good, but they weren't making them at the hour we were there. In addition to our two sausage sandwiches, i also got an order of the potato salad--surprise twist ending: it was german potato salad (duh, it's a german bar...i'm dumb) with bacon in it, served warm! The sandwiches were tasty and i got kraut on my hotlink. We had good beer, and we played some pool.

Things were going really well until a group of kids swarmed the place. Some 8 or 10 of these young people just showed up out of nowhere. Luckily by then, our table at Monk's Kettle finally opened up, so we happily left our unfinished game behind and sauntered off. I like this place a lot, but i guess they can't help the kinds of crowds who come in when they're a cheap dive bar in the Mission.
author: Phuong M.

description: Lots of beer on tap, nice staff, plenty of places to sit, along with videogames-what's not to like?
author: Varun V.

description: Met my boyfriend here, so I guess I am a bit biased when I say I love this bar :)
author: Natalia K.

description:
The Meatwad Sandwich. Oh dear God.

Pastrami. Bacon. Bockwurst. Cheddar. Perfectly proportioned.

Heart attack? Yes. Worth it? Yes. 

This is the best sandwich I've had in a while. If you're not a vegetarian, try it. If you're a vegetarian, stop being silly, and try it. If you're a vegan, I'm pretty sure you'll cry at the mere sight of this. Hell, I cried at the sight of it, but obviously for entirely different reasons. 

Beer: Awesome. Not an immense tap selection but it kept me happy. Hennepin's Farmhouse Saison was especially welcomed. 

Prices: Reasonable. $9 for the sandwich which was my entire caloric intake for the day and $5 beers. 

Verdict: Come here on an off night or afternoon, settle down with this monster of a sandwich and a good beer in the corner couch, and weep from joy.
author: Alejandro B.

description: Great beer selection but apparently Wednesday night means playing 2 Chainz songs so loud you can't hear anything
author: Sonya Z.

description: Went here with my beau for a little snack and drink before a flick at the Roxie and what a disappointment.  The bartender/food prep, guy behind the counter pretty much ignored me while I stood there for about 10 minutes occasionally raising my hand to get his attention when he accidentally looked my way--he was apparently preoccupied with making the perfect sandwich for a customer but could have at least acknowledged my presence, apologized for the lack of service, tell me he'd be with me in just a minute, etc. etc.    Hipsters at the bar were equally smug and insular and made the overall impression of Gestalt Haus quite the negative one.  Will never go to this place again.
author: Shaki S.

description: Came here for a friend's bday last weekend, and they earn some points right off the bat for letting us bring our baby in here (you know, 'cause we're good parents). Excellent beer menu, and the music volume was just right (loud enough to appreciate the selection, not so loud that you couldn't hear anyone at your table). Also had just the right level of scuzziness to make me feel at home.
author: Pat M.

description: Really good music, they played The White Panda and Gossip to funky house beats. Unfortunately I was trying to have a heart-to-heart with an old friend and this was not the bar to do it. If I'm down to dance I would definitely come back here!
author: Letitia L.

description: Came to this joint for the first time first off mad props to the bartender/dj LALO EXTREMELY cool n even suggested some awesome drinks n a mind blowing sausages THANKS YOU GUYS
author: Celissa G.

description:
It's inevitable that I will fall down when I come here. It's not that I'm drunk (I am), but it's because there is this weird stair/floor thing happening between the bar and bathroom that always trips me up.

Other than that, come on. How can one argue with sitting at a bar and shoving meat down your throat? This is the kind of shit that normally gets you in trouble. It's like public indecency. But at Gestalt, it's okay. 

The bartenders are always nice and always more than happy to serve me their meat. They also supply yummy beer to accompany it.

Just avoid this place on a Friday, when the front of the bar is crowded by annoying assholes dancing to annoying 60s pop music. No one wants to eat sausage to that.
author: Pamela D.

description:
Obsessed with all things German, I could not pass this bar up on my way home from BART. The aroma of fresh brats and the merry clinking of steins first reeled me in. Then came the jukebox playing "Beat It" and cool cats hanging out dancing, laughing, and mingling. A minute later, I walked my bike in and parked her up on the rack.

This beer house is one of the coolest bars in the city. Right on the edge of the 16th and Valencia scene, Gestalt draws in a fun and diverse crowd. Everyone is really friendly, even when there's some mad action at the pool table.

I could hang here for hours, cuz it's got everything I'd want right at my fingertips! 

Beer by the stein
Cool bartenders
Hot tasty sausages and potato salad
Killer 80's music
Pool table
Comfortable seating
Indoor bike racks
Clean bathrooms
Easy access outside (to take a call or smoke)

So if you're in the Mission looking to get rubbed by all sorts of body parts and dance in a sweaty, smoke-filled room, then head over to Delirium. But if you're in the mood for a chill, fun night with beers, brats, and pool, then Gestalt is the place to be. Your bike will thank you.
author: Patty L.

description: Dive bar, great selection of beers, variety of sausages and brats = a great night in the  Mission
author: Michelle M.

description:
This place is deceivingly awesome. The decor looks like a fairly typical dive bar with a biker, german twist. From the looks of it, you'd think the food is so, so. You'd be wrong! The food is amazing! Really first class grub. I'm a big fan of Rueben sandwiches and this place has the best one I've ever had, anywhere.

The beer selection is top notch and the staff is friendly.

And to top it off, they have indoor bicycle parking!
author: Derrek P.

description: Awesome beer selection. Menu isn't great and when I went some kind of South Park/ Simpson/ family guy cartoon was playing and it really killed the ambiance and was super annoying.
author: Marianna M.

description:
I came here expecting to experience the best sausage dog I had yet to try, and they delivered just that.

The service was rather slow, but the attendants were genuinely nice people who meticulously prepared our food and made sure our beers were topped off just right.

I ordered the Bockwurst, a combination of veal and pork that the waitress related was the most popular item, and found that it was perfectly juicy and succulent while maintaining a audible "crisp" as I bit into it. I also tried the Italian (they had run out of Kielbasa) vegan sausage, which was good, but not being a fan of faux sausages myself, I much preferred the former.

And of course, the beer selection was amazing! I had the Gnarley Wine on tap, a 10.5% brew which tasted sweet yet had just the kick to it I was looking for. I'm not much of a beer drinker usually, but there were some other interesting varieties that I would certainly come back here just to try.

The ambience was great...sticky but pretty clean for a dive bar. I would definitely recommend this place for its good food, fun atmosphere, and reasonable prices!
author: Amy T.

description:
The lunch was awesome. Big screens, nice pool table. Service was the only thing that could have been friendlier. 
I was impressed overall and i would go back for sure. 4-7 happy hour. the soul on a roll sandwich is amazing. i'm not sure why they stop serving food so early... they have a bunch of creative sandwiches.
author: Jordan S.

description:
Great beer selection
Pool table
Big Buck Hunter
Sandwiches during day hours including "the vegan tuna melt"
Sausages and vegan sausages all night
author: shannon d.

description:
I like the great selection of beers in this place- like the Chocolate Stout. Man, that is worth going into this place alone.  It isn't the best bar in the area, but always worth a visit, and definitely adds to the neighborhood. 

I have never tried the food here unfortuntely. The sausages sound good, but I have always just eaten before rolling in here. 

I can't figure out what this place is trying to be? Yet another hipster spot? Bike messager hangout? A Rosamude type place?  Toronado?
author: Jim B.

description: Great beer selection and so many on tap! fancy glasses and great atmosphere! I didn't try the food but looks like a must! I will definitely come back for more!
author: Kaylen F.

description:
This is a nice, chill neighborhood bar with really outstanding sandwiches. the food is made with love by the proprietors (thanks Hannah and Austin). I've even seen them steaming their own artichokes and making their own horsey sauce. 

I've seen negative comparisons to Toronado here - that makes very little sense. A) Toronado is a douche-bag haven and B) it's focus is beer. While Gestalt has a nice selection, that's not it's primary focus. It's focus is on eating good food while having a good time.
author: Jay N.

description:
Great welcome to the neighborhood.  Great bartenders, great atmosphere, big TVs and big screens, and nice drinks.  AND THEY HAVE AWESOME SANDWICHES.  Fresh home-made aioli!!!  And their vegan/vegetarian options are amazing.  Just had the vegan tuna melt and it was absolutely habit forming. 

Keep it up...
author: David C.

description:
Been here a couple times during the afternoon for a beer & a sausage for lunch because this place was empty while the other more chi-chi places nearby are packed. 

Don't let the dive-like appearance and the lack of waitresses and/or tables scare you away.  It's a great place to watch some sports on TV, catch a nosh & down a brew while in the neighborhood for just $10 including a tip to the bartender/cook.  They also make a great reuben, that I just recently tried, w/freshly baked rye swirl bread & pastrami the barkeep says they import from NYC.
author: Martin C.

description:
Beer and brats... The perfect combo really. We owe much to the Germans for that.  And, as I write this, I'm witnessing the construction of a meaty, chili-infused, bacon-topped dog for some lucky patron.
Oh ja... das ist güd.
author: Matt T.

description: Probably my favorite beer spot in the city. Deschutes Abyss on tap AND in a bottle. Ballast Point Habenero Sculpin. Ninkasi Tricerihops. They even have a Moonlight beer, Twist of Fate. And some Green Flash beers. And like a hundred other beers. Basically, I will satisfy my inner beer geek every time I'm in there, and the prices are super reasonable. No pretentious 'gastro pub' vibe here- it's pretty divey, and that's ok. My husband and I pretty much live at the pac man table. Bonus- lots of pinball machines! Extra bonus- the bartenders are babes.
author: Lynn M.

description: Wow. Wow. I would have given this place 4 stars until the giant ass (I don't use that word lightly) of a bartender literally threw away our food in front of us because he didn't like our attitude.  Disclaimer: we weren't drunk, weren't obnoxious, just literally confused about the side it came with.  He  wouldn't talk to us and wouldn't explain.  Great business sense. Hope he makes the owners proud.
author: Theresa O.

description:
DISCLAIMER: I DJ here. But it is a great gig. (Ska, rocksteady and early reggae vinyl every Friday Happy Hour 7 to 10).

Any place that has a gazillion tap handles of German lagers, pilsners and other quality beer, hot, freshly made sandwiches and grilled sausages, a friendly owner, a divey yet cozy atmosphere and DJs is good by me. 

Daniel is a righteous dude with a good enterprise, he cares about sound and is into it - he recently upgraded his system and it rocks! 

As I am a hophead I love that they always have Racer 5, a double IPA and one other kind of ale (currently Drake's 1500).

Stop by for sandwich and beer during the day, or sausage, beer and/or music at night.
author: Mark G.

description:
Why is it called Gestalt Haus? I was expecting an experience like this:

Bartender: Can I help you?
Matthew: Yes, I would like a pilsner please.
Bartender: Sounds like you want a beer. 
Matthew: Yes, I am very thirsty and also I would like to be drunk.
Bartender: Hmm. Interesting. Focus on that thirst for a moment and describe what it feels like to me.
Matthew: Well, it's a dryness in my throat and -
Bartender: Hold on there for a moment. Start again, and try to begin your sentences with "I feel...". Go ahead.
Matthew: Um, I feel a dryness in my throat and mouth and I'm very warm. When can I have my beer?
Bartender: Good, good, we're making progress. Now imagine that your thirst is standing here next to me. What would you say to it?
Matthew: JUST GET ME A #$%@#& BEER.
Bartender: You sound upset.

But no, the bartenders here are not really interested in your situational awareness, only with getting you the beer you want and taking your sausage order. The beer selection is impressive, high end imports and domestic craft brews with the obligitory I'm-broke option (it's tecate here, I think), all manner of sausages (pork, beef, vegetable protein), and hipsters. lots of those. I think it's the thrift store furniture that calls out to them, or just that it's on 16th street. but whatever, they'll leave you alone if you want to be left alone.  

There are probably better places to go for beer, and better places to go for sausage, but then you'll have to go to two places, and neither of them will likely have a pool table or comfortable thrift store furniture. So it's kind of like target in that respect. A tragically hip target that doesn't have tons of young children running around. I think that's how I'd characterize it.
author: matthew r.

description:
From the outside Gestalt Haus looks just like every other dive-bar that liters the Mission. The lighting is dim, the interior looks gutted, and the bartenders are surly. However, upon closer inspection you'll realize there is something special going on here.

Unlike the normal, run-of-the-mill, dive bars this places serves food -- and not just any food -- real honest-to-god German sausages. Hell yes. I didn't have one, mind you, but they looked absolutely scrumptious. 

I opted out of the sausage for one reason alone: beer.
Gestalt has a decent selection of hard-to-find beers on draft, and several more in bottles/cans, and based on the chalkboard menu I'd guess they switch them around on the regular. But what really makes this great, is you can order any of their drafts beer in a liter glass. Fuck yes. 

Gestalt Haus is definitely on my, Must Visit Again list. Possibly on an upcoming Monday, because I noticed they host a Monday Movie Night on their large projection screen. 

Basically, what I'm trying to say is: Gestalt, I think I like you.

TL;DR -- Liter Draft Beers and German Sausages. If that isn't enough. Fuck off.
author: Gabriel S.

description:
Pretty much nirvana. 

Pool table. check.
Cold beers. check.
Tasty sausages. check.
Comfy places to sit. check.
Pinball machine. check.
Juke box. check.
author: Tim G.

description:
With a slogan like beers, brats, and bikes, what's not to love?!

We ended up here after learning the wait for Monk's Kettle would be an hour and a half. I'm always surprised at how dead the Mission is on Sunday nights but it worked to our advantage at Gestalt. We found a table big enough to accommodate 4, got our songs played on the jukebox, and didn't have to wait for our beers. The bartender was awesome, super knowledgeable about the beers, let us have multiple tastes, and suggested great sausages.  

We all ended up having a fantastic evening, definitely due in part to the friendliness of the bartender.  The beer selection is definitely not as great as that of Monk's Kettle or Toronado's (Pliny the Younger anyone??) but the sausages were juicy and reasonably priced.  Would definitely go back!
author: Sara D.

description:
Okay, the two-star review is only because I used to love this little spot on a great 2-block strip on 16th street between Mission and Guerrero - they have comfortable chairs and have, as someone previously mentioned, multiple types of IPA on tap. However, while they used to price their tap beer similarly to their surrounding neighbors, I was shocked when I recently discovered the hard way that their beers on tap are a whopping SIX DOLLARS! 

How can you be a "dive bar" with prices like that, when your closest competitors - Kilowatt and Delirium to name a couple, along with Elbo Room, charge $4 (Kilowatt $3.75) for the same beer?! If you're going to charge more upscale prices, your establishment has to offer something in return, that's just how it usually is. Now, I'm sure those fixie-loving bike hipsters who have been frequenting this place forever will keep their loyalties, but I have done my best to spread the word to my fellow dive-enthusiasts, that if they're in the area and wanting a good pint for a good price, to stay away from this place.
author: Sean R.

description:
I like this place BUT the bathroom is so disgusting that there is no way this place can get high stars. There is always a combination of 
1. puke
2. piss
3. blood like stuff
4. clogged/not working toilet

It's gross and unsanitary.  Come on guys fix your bathroom, even kilowatts is better

As for the beer and sausages- YUM.
author: Skye W.

description:
I've walked by this place about a gazillion times and have been to pretty much every bar in the area, yet, for some reason, had never stepped foot inside Gestalt until a couple of weeks ago.  Maybe it's because they don't have a big flashy sign like the other bars do or how they've somehow managed to appear as a hole in the wall on 16th St.  I knew it was there, though, and had been meaning to try it, but it wasn't till a friend suggested that we meet up here for drinks the other week that I finally checked it out.

We ventured here on a slow weekday night and discovered that it was mostly a beer place, but also had a small selection of soju and sake with mixers.  My usually wine and cocktails girly self decided to tough it out, though, and opted to order the lightest beer, in the smallest cup.  Oh, shush.  I know.

I ended up having a grand, chill time.  I dig this little nook and its laidback atmosphere.  Uber bonus points that the owner/bartender is a nice fella with great taste in music.  And did I mention that there was food, too?  Not like potato chips and snickers, but sandwiches, potato salad, hot dogs and even vegan dogs.  The good stuff.  The bathroom could use a little work, though, but I'll survive.

Thank goodness I came here with a beer lover, too.  Otherwise, I would not have tasted some of the beers that I did.  I tasted one that had a chocolate-y aftertaste, while the other had that of lychee, and then some.  Beer.  Who knew?

I think I might start liking beer and I don't know if that's a good or bad thing.  Gestalt Haus, I blame it on you.
author: Debbie L.

description: I'm not rating the bathroom, ambiance, or anything besides the "bar experience." It was awesome! The beer is great there and if the owner is bar-tending when you go, you'll get great service! He is great! He knows everything about beer and will actually take a minute to talk to you (even on a friday night) if your not sure what you want or he will recommend something really good. Definitely a better bar amongst the mission lot.
author: Kat C.

description:
My friend, who recently backpacked across Europe, found out about this place through a "Voice Deal of the Day" deal. She envisioned that we would be reliving her European drinking adventures, enjoying our bratwursts, drinking out of boots, etc. After convincing me to purchase one of these coupons, we soon found ourselves too busy to redeem them until a few days before they expired, which brings us to our Tuesday night drinking adventure...

To be honest, we imagined this place to look more like a restaurant (shows how much we knew about this place).  We walked in, and the place looked like a typical bar with a pool table at the front. We ended up ordering bockwurst, which was a mix of veal and pork, and the potato salad, which was served warm and had bacon in it!! Win! After telling the bartender what kinds of beer we liked, he recommended some German beers that he thought we would like, and he was right.  I had the Hoegarden, and my friend had some kind of spaten.

No drinking out of boots this time around...we'll save it for our next visit!
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
The owner - Daniel .. rocks!

I made two suggestions about a month ago:  1) get the bathroom door to lock with a big dead bolt  2) Upgrade the speakers to true PA level speakers.  He did!  It works!   And .. Awesome!!!

The bathroom now .. just works.  As it should be it is now worry free

Also - the PA system Rocks!!!   It just sounds terrific.  No hiss. No blare. No empty/oud effect.   It is now the real deal stuff.   Powerful/ clear/ present/ good.

Thanks for taking my suggestions.  Now - time for more beers at Gestalt.

MW
author: mario w.

description:
Rude staff, terrible food. Go to Safeway and cook the same sausage yourself

Apparently if the sandwich guy calls in sick, they can't make sandwiches, pretentious no?
author: Eric B.

description:
Gestalt Haus received great reviews but I'm here to lower their overall scoring.  Additionally, this will be the last time I go to a crappy dive bar because my boy friend planned it out with his friends.  We were suppose to meet up for last minute drinks and food at 6pm.  Okay, not a big deal, except this place stops serving food to Chinese people at 6pm.  Why would I say such a thing?  We arrived at 6.03pm.  Our non-Asian friend ordered food before we arrived and I asked the bar tender if I could have their special.  He said they were all out, rips the sign off the wall, and walked away.  When I finally got his attention again and asked for a menu, he said there was no food available.  They only served food for lunch while my friend was being served at 6.10pm.  

There is a shift change and next thing I notice food was being prepared and served.  I am not pleased to say the least.  I tried to get the attention of the new tender (if for nothing but to refill my empty beer glass).  Things quickly got worse, the new tender throws a full stein of beer across the bar, across at least 5 customers, hits the walls, drenches beer over a ladies' purse, cell phone, and date.  A foul shout match between the tender and about 3 Middle Eastern ex-customers ensue for about 2 minutes.  The bartender does not offer to help the beer soaked customers clean up.  He does offer us a round of free beer but must have noticed the one Asian outlier and never gave us any beer.  

To make a shitty evening worse, we go to a Vietnamese restaurant afterwards which gave me the runs and my boy friend stayed out with another group of friends until 3am...FML (different website but I think the clause fits)
author: Linda W.

description:
Every time I try to take friends out in SF it's the same story- we eat dinner and then there is always a push to go to Kilowatt.  It's always crazy overcrowded to the point where you can't move...so we head across the street to Gestalt.  And Gestalt is always the perfect place that has the perfect amount of busy- there are plenty of people in there, but you can usually find a place to sit, play pool after a short wait, and get a delicious beer.  It's very nice in there with a good, friendly vibe.  You can actually hear your friends talk.

Now that I see the Yelp reviews, I realize that I have been missing out on the food.  Dear Gestalt: I am sorry I did mentally put you in the same category as Zeitgeist and assumed your food would be lame.  Next time I will be there early to partake in your gastronomic delights!

Next time I will just bring everyone straight to Gestalt.  It doesn't deserve to be the back-up choice anymore.
author: Erika W.

description:
Let me start off by saying I am allergic to hops.  This means no beer for Brian.  Fuck my life, right?  I manage.  So for me to give a place that primarily serves beer a 5 star review is a big deal.

The beginning:  I would come here on psuedo-dates to play pool in the afternoon and have some vegan sausage.  Spacious, not too busy, sunny, great snausage.  I is happy.

The finale:  Ended up here on new years eve.  Fuck me I had so much fun.  The bouncer was nice as hell, telling me about the non-beer options for me to drink.  The bartender even remembered my friend and I who used to come but hadn't been in months.  I had a few of the SoJo drinks as they call them (I think that's right), which is a semi-liquor (I guess you don't need a liquor license for it) and was totally happy.  And then free champagne at midnight!

Ended up coming back two nights later to another packed house and more friendly staff.

Now, I have mixed feelings about the mission.  However, this place seems to either attract the radest people in the area, or mellows them out to awesomness by radiating it's own radness as a business (that was a fun sentence).

Gestalt, you have my heart.
author: Brian G.

description: Sausage & Beer!  What more can you ask for?  I like this place because it's not as crowded as Rosamunde.  I guess not as many people have found out about it.  This is an awesome place to hit up in San Francisco!
author: Johnny L.

description:
When it comes to "Bars" this is one of my favorites if not my favorite bar in the Mission.

The best beer selection around and cool bar tenders.

The food is excellent too.

Lota freaks and weirdos in there though.  That includes me.
author: Shawn L.

description:
Lately I've decided Gestalt IS Zeitgeist Junior. =)

If you don't know the bartenders, or stare at them lookin annoyed, you'll get ignored. 
It IS the default overflow point for most 16th st bars but also has it's own cult following of friends. If beer was more my preference i would be here more often but i prefer the hard A they don't have.

What i love:
- Lunch with them, watching BS TV, talkin news or cash cab. 
- The pool tables almost always open.
- The bartenders really are a lil family of sweethearts once you get to know them. 
- The random psytrance-esqe visuals they've been projecting on DJ nights LOL not their usual atmosphere, but 2 persona's works for me.

What's real about them:
- They can be Crass, they can piss people off, but like Zeitgeist, they own it - it's part of the place, the vibe, the culture, it's not for everyone. If they weren't the lovable assholes they can be, they wouldn't tolerate half the rowdiness that goes on there. Cheers!

Sandwiches:
16th St Hotel or the Meatwad - and free delivery on $15+ orders is excellent!
author: Pierre V.

description:
Look, I'd give this place three stars but I experienced a slow, creeping weird vibe here. And no, it wasn't just me this time. The bar staff seem friendly enough though certain regulars.... 

Once upon a time there were many, many motorcycles clustered around this Mission spot. Not so much today though the dark, and the pool table, and the patrons' biker styles suggest the machinery is only out of sight and not out of mind. I like the slight German beer garden theme: long tables, huge glass tankards, traditional food offerings like hot brats, sauerkraut, and warm potato salad. Simple and tasty. 

Hit Gestalt early during a pub crawl for the experience. But no need to linger.
author: Poet D.

description: Great beer selection of stouts, IPAs, pilsners and plenty of our specialties for beer fanatics. Has a great divey, laid-back vibe with pool tables, stool tables and regular tables. The bartenders are very cool people, will give you some info. on any type of beer and match to the genre you prefer.
author: Michael B.

description: Friendly bar tender, awesome sandwiches and a great atmosphere. I'd go here just for the sandwiches. The beer list is pretty amazing too.
author: Desi N.

description:
My new favorite dive bar in the mission.

Pool table.

Great selection of beer on tap.

AWESOME sandwiches. They serve 'em late too. Sure beats the 3 hour wait at Ikes
author: John M.

description:
I wish i could give this place a better review .. the beers and sausages are awesome .. but the staff and cliental are terrible !!! 
worth going for a beer or bite .. but not a fav in san francisco
author: Micah W.

description:
This place is like half lounge-half dive bar. You walk in and there is a lounge area with comfy sitting arrangements on the right and a pool table on the left. As you walk further in there is a rack to hang your bicycle, then raised podium for a dj, and then the bar. 

I felt at home immediately. Good beers on tap, including one from the moonlight brewing company in Santa Rosa.

My date and I came in to play pool and have a few drinks. We ended up making friends with a couple of guys who were also there to play pool. It was a fine night out. 

The bar is in a great location on 16th near Valencia, about a half block down from the Roxie Theater.

I'll definitely be returning to this spot.
author: David K.

description: My go-to bar on 16th: great people, quality beer selection, super-friendly guys, and delicious sausages.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Gestalt! You hipster haven, you! With your fun muraled bathroom walls, your draft beer selection, your sausages...wait. Aren't you a vegetarian, Ashley? Yes, yes, I am. And Gestalt caters to my particular predilection by offering not one, but two, vegetarian sausage options. Which are delicious. So...what's not to like, right? PREEEEEcisely what I says to myself.

Back when the Mission didn't have a 20-50% chance of making me upchuck in my mouth, I thought this place was THEE SHIZ. I mean, you can get a liter of beer and a sausage for really reasonable prices, and the beer choices are really quite impressive. And now that I'm not as much of a fan of the Mission as I once was, I'm still a fan. 

While my relationship w/ San Francisco may fluctuate depending on my mood and the amount of self-righteous douchebaggery I see whilst making the short trek from BART to the bar, there isn't much that can ruin Gestalt for me. The beer selection is impressive, whether you're looking for something light, hoppy, dark, sophisticated, Belgian, whatever. They have a beer for all palates...assuming, that is, that you're a beer drinker. And the sausages!! Well, I won't lie and pretend that I care about any of the actual meat options, but there are a few, and I'm sure they taste much as a sausage should. What I care about are my VEGAN SAUSAGE options. What makes a me happier than a big ol' beer and a fake sausage on a sunny and/or rainy day? Well, quite a few things, but that's beside the point. The vegan sausages are delicious. They aren't some lame soy hot dogs with no flavor (although I enjoy those bad boys, too). Gimme a big, dark beer, a vegan sausage, some sauerkraut, and some mustard/sauce options and watch as I dissolve into a sloppy puddle of joy. 

The bartenders aren't rude, which is nice. The beer selection makes me happy. Prices are reasonable. Location is convenient. And they have vegan tuna melts??? Damn. Why don't I come here more often?
author: Ashley M.

description:
There is a reason we all try yoga, pretend to meditate, take long walks with our French bulldogs and other such activities. We are seeking balance. There is almost always too much of something and not enough of something else in our mixed-up, little lives.

Balance is equally important in the sandwich world. Most sandwiches have way too much of one thing and not enough of something else. Sandwiches from Jewish Delis pile on enough meat to choke a lion, to-go sandwiches are hopelessly bread heavy, and a certain chain squirts on mayo like its going out of style. 

The sandwiches served at Gestalt Haus don't have too much of anything and the ingredients blend together like a delicious, edible symphony. Take my favorite option, "The Ray Davies." This baby features bacon dripped with honey, cheddar cheese, slice apples and house aioli, served up on 7-grain bread. Each ingredient offers something lovely and doesn't try to take over the show. They have several other awesome choices including "The Dre Dog" (Boars head honey glazed chicken, Swiss cheese, roasted red peppers, bacon and house aioli) and the "Ferdinand the Bull" (Roast beef, onions, lettuce, tomato, Swiss cheese, home-made horse radish aioli served on a hot garlic role). All sandwiches come with either potato salad or sliced apples. For your entertainment they have a pool table, pinball machine, Buck Hunter and several very good beers on tap and in the bottle. 

So if you're looking for balance in your life and you've eaten too many mediocre sandwiches, drank too many so-so beers and not killed nearly enough electronic animals lately its time to head on down to Gestalt where you don't need a yoga mat to find your Zen.
author: Heather R.

description:
The best pastrami sandwich in San Francisco! This is a great bar with an excellent beer selection but what really sets it apart is the food. Its not your typical bar food, they serve super tasty sausages and hot sandwiches. I grew up in Brooklyn and one of the things I miss the most on the west coast is the pastrami. Gestalt has great hot pastrami piled high on rye bread with spicy brown mustard and a crispy kosher dill pickle,  just like home.

It's a great neighborhood bar with a laid back atmosphere, great food and beer, and friendly bartenders. What more could you ask for.
author: Steele D.

description:
It hurts me to have to take off a star from my previous review, but it needed to be done. I was there with some friends last night and the staff made some serious no-nos that I had to Yelp about.

Issue #1: My friend ordered a sausage around 10:20pm or so, and the bartender responded that they were out of sausage. A nearby staff member replied there they were not actually out of sausage, and the bartender told my friend that they were done serving food for the night. Within 15 minutes, we saw another group picking up 2 sausages. WTF, man? Not cool.

Issue #2: This is my BIG grievance with Gestalt last night. The DJ SUUUUUUUCKED. She was some hipster girl who was playing such shitty bar music; slooow-ass, boring 80's music. Playing 80s is one thing, but she only played the slowest ones. After every song ended, my group and I would audibly heckle the DJ's terrible playlist and yell for something upbeat. She responded by turning the music up... that little bitch. If I owned a business where the patrons typically liked to come and drink at least 2 liters of beer, I would want them to enjoy themselves and play the music they want to hear, lest I'd have to deal with 2 to 3 liters worth of anger.

She wasn't getting it. Every single song ended with me screaming, "Hey DJ Power Trip, play better music already!!!" and giving her disapproving expressions every time she looked in my direction. At one point, my friend and I mocked her by slow-dancing in front of the DJ booth at full-arm's length with nervous expressions, like the middle school dances this bitch is apparently used to working at. 

I eventually finished my beer, waited until the song was over so that the DJ could clearly hear me screaming that she completely sucked dick at entertaining us all night, and returned home as the proud owner of one of the massive glass steins that Gestalt serves liters of beer in.

As far as beer and sausage, the place is still as good as it gets. Minus one star for the TERRIBLE DJ.
author: Ramsey D.

description:
Beer = solid variety, comes in three sizes (pints, 1/2 liter, liter)

Sausages = comes in the pork, the beef, the veggie, the all-tasty varieties

Atmosphere = chill + divey/charming, couches + pool table, bike racks + jukebox

Sum: Gestalt Haus = WIN

Gestalt is one of, like, eight bars within stumbling distance of my apartment, and I've been there the most, thus far. Because it's a winner. I like hanging out with winners. It makes me feel cooler by default.
author: Anna G.

description:
Another skanky dive bar in Mission. We spent way too much time here as our last stop of a pub crawl. All I remember is playing pool and losing a lot. I think my teammate and I were supposed to buy our opponents dinner but we were so drunk by the time we got to dinner that we all forgot. 

Why does it seem like everyone in this damned city is an alcoholic? I couldn't wait to fly home and hang out with sober friends again.
author: Pierre Trudeau I.

description:
Hi Gestalt, so, like, one dollar off your regularly priced beer is not a very good happy hour, especially when your tap beer are $6 each.  No way, Jose!  Sorry,  but much nicer joints have better priced happy hours than Gestalt, inclusive of superior atmosphere, you know, right?  

However, the NF in my Myers-Briggs scale loves, loves, LOVES the fact that this place unofficially "hires" the homeless as barbacks... although essentially I know it's a tax-free way of getting someone to clean up glasses without the payroll expense (let alone Healthy SF!).  Still, it seems like a well intentioned shout-out and that's good PR.

The Friday happy hour bartender was amazing.  He worked very hard and was extremely quick and charming, in spite of this establishment's overly expensive happy hour.
author: Sasha S.

description:
Indoor bike rack.. sandwiches along with the sausages, and nice beers on tap. Yay. Oh and hipsters. Yes, the hipsters. Hey, this is the Mission, what's a bar without hipsters?

I went here because they had an art opening for my friend (which was VERY cool by the way). I love places that show local art and support the art community. Good job, Gestalt Haus!
author: Reese W.

description:
It has beer, sausages and TVs that in my book already rates 3 stars.  
Cool place to kick it before a Roxie show or when you just want to grab a drink and bite.  Of course it's no Toronado & Rosamunde.  

The rockwurst sausage I ordered was a bit on the dry side, but still pretty delish with a nice pile of sauerkraut to top it off.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
This is a trippy litlle place.  You can't call it a dive bar as they only have beer and wine (that's a rule).
I'm sure it's totally different at night but when I went in it was very nice.
They have many beers and sausage as reported over and over but the staff (Austin and Pam) were very nice.
author: Richard L. D.

description:
What separates this joint from your average dive bar is the gentle manner of the proprietors and the attention they pay to the details of the food they serve. You're always welcomed with a smile and you won't want for friendly conversation at the bar, which offers a dozen superb beer choices, equally weighted between balanced German brews, Belgian (and -style) selections, and a few local choices, including the lovely Brit-style Napa Smith Pale Ale. 

The attention to detail in their food is admirable. The sausage buns are carefully selected, Their ingredients are local and fredh. Just today I witnessed them steaming fresh artichokes for sandwiches so that they don't have to use canned ones anymore. And the tomatoes? Heirlooms. 

This place should be busier, and they should charge a bit more, hopefully the latter before the former. I look forward to returning soon.
author: Tim T.

description:
Such an odd pub. They have this big screen playing soft-core porn, trippy psychedelic music with overlaying vocals from Barry Gibbs playing in the background, and a constant traffic of homeless people walking in asking for change. 

Definitely not going back.
author: Michael C.

description:
Walk into Gestalt Haus, you'll notice all the great beers they have on tap. Given the vibe and environment, what you wouldn't think is that they have any kind of good quality of food. Wrong. 

On their sandwich board outside, they brag about their Reuben. I thought... yeah, right. But I ordered it. The cole slaw was not good -- I think it was a little old and mushy -- though I did order less than an hour before their kitchen closed. 

Regardless, the Reuben -- holy crap. Sooooo good, and I've had Reuben sandwiches all over the city. I'm not sure what they put into it, but it's easily the best one I've ever had on the West Coast. Goodness. I'm officially addicted. Wow.
author: Jack L.

description:
I really like this place.  Anywhere I can get Double Daddy on tap I am a very happy!

According to previous posts, since I like this place, I am a "hipster".  I am not sure most people think of me that way. Why are people comming to the Mission and complaining about hipsters?!

If you like good beer, bikes and brat, this is the place for you. I had the meat and found it excellent!  And the staff have always been very nice as well.
author: Alan L.

description:
After a long absence and a shocking return, I must drastically change my review here. Gestalt Haus is no longer the rustic, beer-lover's bicyclist destination it once was. It is now, in fact, a generic, boring, and inappropriately flashy bourgeois hangout. The young and stylish danced to loud hip-hop music, whereas before, scruffy (but still young and stylish) cyclists brooded over enormous liter-mugs of beer, playing Led Zeppelin on the juke-box. Now the indoor bicycle rack has vanished, and so, it seems, have the comely bicycle boys. They now serve ale in fancy tall glasses instead of comically oversized mugs, and, in my humble opinion, the worst transgression of all, they no longer serve my favorite ale, Fat Tire. Too plebian for them now, I imagine. They now only serve extremely crafty and foreign beers I've never heard of or do not care for.

So sad, this pub had much promise. In a few years, it may have even become a proper dive. But alas, it's gone astray and will never be the same again. Needless to say, I shall not set foot in Gestalt Haus ever again.
author: Mortimer P.

description:
My friend dragged me here to prove that there are bars in the mission which aren't entirely overrun by hipsters. I was highly dubious, but low and behold he was right! I quickly came to the conclusion that the Abercrombie vibe was decidedly more acceptable than the Kilowatt vibe.
Plus, the beer was fancy-tasting. I'll be back to try the food and pool tables.
author: Claire C.

description:
I like Gestalt a lot! If you're wondering why I only gave it three stars, it's because I would have given it 4 stars except for the bathroom situation, which is a BIG ding.

C'mon now, you cannot have ONE bathroom for both men and women in a beer-heavy bar! Some of us are stricken with Tiny Bladder Syndrome, which means we need to piss after every delicious beer on tap that you serve (and by the way, the beers on tap are GREAT. They have a fantastic selection of rotating taps and beers in bottles as well). But one bathroom?? I feel bad for the men who have to wait for us ladies to do our business. Cuz we womenfolk are SLOW. I guess they could always just go outside and pee on the walls? 

Please, Gestalt, add another bathroom. I'm just asking for ONE more, that's all, and I'll be much happier and come to your lovely little bar more often.

The bar itself is neat. Small, dark but not so dark that you can't see who you're about to make out with (which may or may not be a good thing). There's not a ton of seating but it makes more sense to have more standing room areas, which is what Gestalt has. They also have two ledges at the front so you can lean, flirt and look at people pissing on the walls outside (For the record, I have never seen anyone piss on the walls, but it's the Mission so I won't be surprised if I do, and given the bathroom situation...). There is also a pool table at the front, and Big Game Hunter in the back. Fun atmosphere, low-key, nice people. I have met some really fun, nice people at Gestalt. The bartenders I've experienced have all been hard-working and attentive. Yes, they could use more bartenders but maybe they're balancing their bartender to bathroom ratio (I need to get over the bathroom situation, I know, I know).

I believe the beers on tap ran about $6, though I was a little drunk so I can't remember clearly. Prices are not super cheap but also not overpriced so they are on par. Cash only, like many places in the Mission. It usually doesn't get as crowded as Elixir, Killowat or 500 Club on the weekends.

I've not had their food but maybe next time. After they get a second bathroom, that is.
author: Logan The H.

description:
It's been my lifelong (read: 6-month-old) dream to stop in at Gestalt Haus on my way home from work, hang my bike on the wall, and get a quick pint and sausage.  Now that's a commute I can believe in.  But to my surprise there was not a single bike in the place.  I was so baffled I ended up leaving mine outside.

At any rate, most of these sausage-&-beer operations are epically sprawling biergartens (Broken Record or Zeitgeist), some even taking it so far as to be technically two separate entities (like Toranadosamunde's).  Gestalt Haus, on the other hand, inverts the concept with a very compact feel.  And while this would be genius in, say, West Portal, at 16th & Mission I'm not so sure there's enough bar to go around, at least on Saturday night (though admittedly, I'm not sure of any Mission bar that I really dig on Saturday).

But a happy hour chowdown on Hawaiian-Portuguese(!) sausage washed down with unfamiliar beers from familiar brands (like Speakeasy's White Lightning Wheat or Moonlight's Twist of Fate Bitter)--what's not to like about that?
author: Wes M.

description:
Grilled Cheese Kimchee Sandwich!



However, I propose it be called the 'Kim-cheese.'
author: alexander r.

description: I was in San Francisco for 2 days. I had to go to Gestalt. I had seen the Kruovice beer on the web page and my mouth watered.  Once in the place there was no Kruovice. Bartender said they were going to get it again. Bartender does look menacing but hey, he is busy getting everyone's order and doesn't have time to have a conversation with you. Bartender provided samples and was fair with his time with me. I would definitely go back and have some more beer and sausage. Great Motown tunes playing that evening. Check this place out. It's not a Four Star Hotel it's a Bar, what did you expect people.  They have a great beer selection, great sausages and good music.
author: Traveler 9.

description:
I used to love this place.Honestly.I got to know the bartenders, and grew to love it, growing up in Germany, and being an avid cyclist.(Great German beer, and bike racks inside.) Yet since Murphy left it just sucks.All of the things that I never noticed before became glaringly obvious.Kind of like finding out that wacky, eccentric Uncle everyone knows and loves is actually a pedophile.

The bathrooms somehow have gotten even worse, and last time I went got into a fisticuffs with a drunk guy who swore I broke in front of him.Never mind I had been waiting in line for nearly 30 minutes.

The crowd now sucks.It used to be a great mix of bike couriers, hipsters, nerdy types, and your usual assortment of drunks.Now it's all underage hipsters, and douchebags drifting over from Monk's that look as if they just got through sailing.I don't like sailing or contributing to the delinquency of a minor.

Not to mention they now have a DJ?What fucking moron decided to bring in a DJ to that tiny bar?Do they expect people to dance in there?Why is it every fucking bar owner gets this great idea to bring bands or a DJ into a dive bar the size of my living room?Do you really think that's going to make things better?


Anyways the only thing they have going for them is cheap regional German brews I practically had in my baby bottle growing up.Frankly I would rather pay an extra dollar or two per beer, in a bar I actually enjoy.I miss the old Gestalt.
author: Joshua T.

description:
I love this place. I spent parts of both Halloween and New Year's here last year, and both were a blast. I've also spent several random afternoons and evenings here, and had some quality conversation with the owner. 

It's particularly good in the non-peak hours when you can actually get a pool table. And they always have some seriously good beer on tap. Like Hop Stoopid. They clearly know the way to my IPA-loving heart.

Tip: Get the seats by the windows if you're there early enough. The people-watching on 16th while drinking your delicious beer can't be beat!
author: Kristen B.

description:
I love beer, bikes and sausage. And not necessarily in that order. Gestalt Haus is dark, sparse, has a swell assortment of beers on tap and a pool table. I usually hate TV's in bars but they were showing the Tour de France and, as a result, was largely ignored by the bartender save for my basest needs (beer.) So basically this place is right up my alley.

I only wish I had brought my bike to slide into the ample indoor bike racks to give me some street cred.
author: Josua P.

description:
No one has said it yet, but I will: I like the combination of Toronado & Rosamunde better. I like the feeling of looking up at the board and being overwhelmed with choices. Am I gonna go big and get a Duvel? Should I be girly and get a Lindemann's? Should I impress this dude & get Death & Taxes? You know how it is. I thought their beer selection was pretty limited, although I appreciate the fact that they carry my very beloved Delirium Tremens and allowing me to walk through the bar with my girly little cup like the entitled Laguna Beach ex-pat that I sooooo obviously am.

There's also my very personal issue with people who are obsessed with bikes, as I went to a college full of people completely obsessed with them and I still cringe a little whenever I see an unwashed guy with messy hair, a pant leg up and a Nalgene bottle. And then I have sexual fantasies about them. I am a conflicted person.
author: Maria D.

description:
Last time I was in Gestalt (that would be the night I managed to get home but don't quite remember how) we used science to ascertain something very important: the fancy and highly phallic .5-liter Trumer glasses hold more than 1.25 times the amount of beer that fits in the standard pint glass.  

This proves two things:
First, it proves that either that the pint glasses are smaller than a pint, or that the .5 liter glasses are bigger than they purport to be, since a liter is technically 2.11 pints.

Second, and more important, the half liter of Trumer for $5 is a better deal than the pint for $4.
author: Joe C.

description:
Started the night at Zeitgeist and ended it at Gestalt Haus - bout ready to jump on a plane to Germany.  The music played covered the gammit of os mutantes and something or other from the dirty dancing soundtrack, but oddly enough, it worked.  The food was amazing and most welcome after a long weekend of heavy drinking, the crowd friendly.  

Oh, and sorry nice bartender, I really didn't attempt to drunkenly follow you into the employee backroom, just looking for the bathroom.  Next time, more sausage, less beer.
author: Amy S.

description:
I stopped in here on Sunday evening to catch up with some friends. Gestalt is a pretty laid back bar and on quieter nights - when it's not overrun by bike messengers - it's a great spot to chill out over a couple of pints (or liters) of choice brew. 

Our bartender seemed genuinely excited to be there, and the crowd there was a mish mash of Mission hipsters, random people who needed a respite from shopping, a couple of older hippies and us. I particularly liked the jukebox, which had enough of a mix to easily spend $5 and then some.

You can sit at the bar, or grab a big table, and definitely come hungry - they also make some really delicious varieties of sausages which serve as a meal in themselves - but go even better with their German potato salad.

P.S. I hear they have a secret back outdoor area, waiting for zoning approval, so keep an eye on that "Keep Out" door in back.
author: Nish N.

description:
The scene:  Oktoberfest 2002.  

The place: Munich Germany

Beers consumed: 2.5 liters of pretty potent German beer.

Food eaten: 2 Huge pretzels, and countless bratwursts.

The weirdest thing I saw:  Their popular "stand up on the table and sing a song" choices.
1) "I wanna know, If you be my girl"...I believe it was from Dirty Dancing.
2) "Take Me Home Country Roads"...although not a fan of the song...at least I could sing along.  
It was just odd.  Love of America I guess.

The scene: Lets go out for beers 2007

The place: Gestalt House, The Mission

Beers consumed: Just .5 liters this time.  Although, with 4-5 different Speakeasy brews on draft, and a multitude of sizes to choose from, it was hard to stay away from the full liter glasses.  I needed to maintain my "sobriety" so I could make it to another bar.  I'll be back for the biggun.

Food eaten:  When given only 2 choices, I chose the Chicken Jalapeno sausage.  Although I believe another in my party ended up with mine, and I ended up with the Chicken Garlic....it was still awesome.  Covered in sauerkraut, these organic sausages are delightful.  They have a vegan option too.

The weirdest thing I saw: A bigger bike rack than most bike shops.  Most definitely a biker bar.  Lots of fixed gears and rolled up pant legs.  This was the first time I was in here as the first bar I made it too.  Usually I'm unaware of everything before I even get here. 

Although both my pant legs were rolled down, and I took the bus here...I still had a good time, and would come back for big beers and sausage.
author: Lauren F.

description:
I LOVE beer. Got that? LOVE IT. But I also LOVE tequila. 

One star for beer. One for sausages. One for the bartender. One for the jukebox. 0 stars for tequila.
author: Kathryn T.

description:
Whenever my good friend Joe C. convinces me to leave the cocoon that is my cozy house and meet him for a drink, he invariably chooses Gestalt Haus. It's mere blocks from BART, a handful of blocks from my house, and conveniently located in the goodness that is 16th St. between Church and So. Van Ness. 

Even with the myriad of bars to be found there, Gestalt is always the choice for a mid-week happy hour. The beers (by the liter) are cheap and good, the sausages and brats hit the spot, and there's always somewhere to sit at the bar. 

The crowd is invariably young and scruffy and there's usually some bike race to watch on tv. On cold nights, it's nice and warm in there, due to the questionable ventilation, and many ovens going behind the bar. 

On the other hand, on warm nights, it's downright sweltering in there. That's not going to keep me from coming back, though, after all, how many warm nights do we really have here?
author: Rachel F.

description:
You know when folks joke and say they only workout when they do curls with 12ounce beers?  Well... I found the place where you can actually walkout looking like Popeye on spinach.  Talk about lots of beer.. a liter!  I know I can drink but damn a liter of beer?  I saw grown ass men using two hands to hold their mugs.  Yes, I was one of the gents switching hands every other minute trying not to drop my beer.  

I don't have a bike but I thought it was nice that they have a bike rack inside the bar for those scared that someone might steal their back tire ;0)

-1 star for the music.  I didn't see anything new.  The closest I came to hip hop was Michael Jackson- Billy Jean.  To where I had to hear Salty B say, "Michael Jackson isn't hip hop."  I know I know.

Mad props to Kevin for making sure myself and everyone else didn't have  to wait long for a beer.
author: Jamal G.

description:
This place has some great beers, but if you're looking for some liquor you might want to move on up or down the street.

This is a nice lounge spot that has a laid back feel and small open area to dance in as you walk toward the bar.  The one weakness at this place...is the bathroom!  The worst bathroom I  have ever seen ever!...A person doesn't deserve to die in this bathroom...yes, I said that!  This bathroom is so freakin rotted!  I felt so bad for the ladies in line that had to use this joints bathroom!  I felt so bad, that I offered one of the women that used it after me a drink in congratulations for getting the job done!

I haven't got to try any of the sausages they advertise to eat while you down some beers, but look forward to it next time.  Good place, but beware of bathroom.
author: Mark L.

description: I saw Puck the the original Real World here and he couldn't stop talking about The Real World. It bummed me out.
author: Matt B.

description:
One of those guys was here last night. A jeans guy. Not the slim guy wearing crazy tight chicks jeans all embroidered to hell, bless their cotton socks, but the guy in those hippy jeans that are actually Uber Jeans made up from the parts of many pairs of lesser jeans. Basically Hippy Frankensteins Jean Monster, a real dogs dinner. I don't know if the guy was Dutch or from Walnut Creek, but those are the only explanations for those damn jeans I can contemplate. It looked like at least 15 pairs of mostly ugly jeans had to die so that he might achieve his goal douchiness.

Anyhow, nice weenies here. Nice beers and staff too. Nice to be able to get a litre of beer also. Looks like your hauling back on an entire pitcher which has a lovely, robust visual lyric to it. Chug, chug, etc.

The place is both dimly lit and has a few too many lights. Weird, but you'll get it when you see the place. Oog, tame suburban sports bar jukebox I've got to say. work on that. Reminded me of when every  bar in SF, hipster or otherwise, had the same 60 CDs on the juke. You couldn't get out of the 500 Club without hearing every Brian Adams song AND Dire Straits Walk Of Life 19 times. Dark days. Between jeans guy and Have I Told You Lately That I Love You coming on (at least it wasn't Rod Stewarts---burp---version) I almost dropped an unforgiving Three Stars on this place.

But there are many things to recommend about a friendly open space for beer and weenies. A place where people can get beer-drunk and not have to find their bike gone but the lock still attached to a parking meter. A place where your vegan friends endless prattle can be temporarily stilled by Gestalt's vegan weenies served on vegan buns. A place where a mangy, hippy, run-down, bolshie coffee place used to sit, where no weenies and few beers were available. 

Insofar as a world without beer and sausage is not one I wish to live in, Gestalt is the better end of the deal.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
Google tells me that "Gestalt" is German for "a configuration or pattern of elements so unified as a whole that it cannot be described merely as a sum of its parts."  Which means, actually, that it doesn't mean anything at all.  Even in German.  

After searching for parking for 30 minutes all over the Mission, my friends and I finally made it in, only to be sneered and snickered at (in the hippest, bike-messenger way possible, of course) by the patrons inside, who of course, rode their uber hip, shiny fixies (that is "hipster-speak" for fixed-gear bike, suckers) and neatly parked them inside.  

This place is large, but has limited seating and a large boxy bar, which lends it a nice, roomy feel, even when it starts to get crowded.  I'm not entirely sure how the geometry of the room contributes to this...  it must be just a certain "je ne sais quois."  There is a great selection of beer on tap, warm potato salad , and brats on the menu (uh, I mean, sausages...  not bitchy whiners...  though, I'm sure there are plenty of those around too).

I'll return when I can figure out how to wear my hair tied back into a ponytail, yet still leave the front tousled and messy (I can only describe it as the modern hipster equivalent of a mullet--party in the front, business in the back!).  Oh, and also when the bottoms of my jeans shrink and tighten around my ankles so  as to create a triangular sausage effect with my legs.
author: vicarious c.

description: As a bar it's pretty cool. Great friendly bartenders, great food (get a sausage and some potato salad) and decent beer selection. I think the biggest problem is the super loud music that seems to happen at 8pm+ It's like I can hear every conversation in the bar, some background music then 1 second later I can't even hear the person I am sitting with. No I didn't shout, "Get off my lawn!" or "Back in my day we were considerate of others listening preferences," ... but I mean it's not like it's a club. Oh well.
author: Greg G.

description:
Parking in the Mission leaves be bitter and angry!  Okay...I mean MORE bitter and angry...

Still, booze cures all ails and I was on my way to self-medicate at Gestalt Haus!

The crew had their asses firmly planted in the huge worn beer stained arm chairs in the front window so my ass plopped down beside them.  The place smelled like stale beer and food.   An oddly comforting aroma, seeing as I have been drinking beer at bars since college, it strikes a chord inside me.  

Sipping my Trumer Pilsner I thought about how my beer tastes have graduated (thankfully) from Bud Light.  I used to drink pitchers of that stuff in college!!! Ahhaah....I was alcohol ignorant.  

Then I see a big dude striding into the bar....
'HOLY SHIT IT'S BIG RED!!!!"

If anyone went to Cal before 2001 and EVER went to Kip's you know EXACTLY who that is....

He works at Gestalt...and this time he's behind the bar.   Dude...that is some crazy shit.  This guy was at the beginning of my affair with booze!  He was the bouncer that helped me ring in my 21st birthday!  Gestalt is WAY better than Kip's.  Even more so....I feel hella safe there cuz if anything goes down Big Red will most definitely regulate on some mother fuckers!!!
author: Jay H.

description:
On the merits of the food, beer selection, and atmosphere, Gestalt would get four stars.  They get five because the bartender was a class act and gave me a free beer to compensate me for my bockwurst being a little late.

The bockwurst was delicious -- plump, creamy, generous heap of sauerkraut on top.  The Twist of Fate Bitter was way more bitter than an "English style" IMO, but after my tastebuds acclimated it was palatable.  The Young's Double Chocolate was a nice smooth stout with an aftertaste like chocolate milk.  

Atmosphere: homey, lively, but not too loud.  Wasn't jam-packed, even on a Friday night.  Definitely a nice place for a quick bite and a brew.
author: Sam S.

description:
The owner of this place is a total bitch.  He came by our table and told my friend to drink up his beer because he was running out of glasses.  We told him to buy some more fucking glasses, I got 2 cases of them at home for fucking $.75 a piece.  It's called Smart & Final.

Then he came back and made some comment about customer service being a two way street, and we told him what we really thought, that his bar sucks and it's a cheap imitation of Toronado and he told us that the customer service there sucks.  My GF told him that she's been going there for over a decade and we always get excellent service and we wouldn't dare eat his George Foreman sausages.  

Fucking new yorkers... buy up all the real estate you want, but don't try to open a bar for locals.

BTW your draft system is jacked up... your Brother David's taste like its got soda water mixed into it.

***Update:

So the next night we went to Toronado, we definitely spent over $100 in beer between the 4 of us after a birthday dinner elsewhere.  I think we spent $15 at Gestalt before the owner started telling us about customer service... good one buddy.
author: SC ..

description:
Great.  I now live next door to Zeitgeist "Lite".  

pfffft.
author: Karen F.

description:
This place is alright for what it is, but the overall feelings are mixed.
The bartender called me "lass", which makes me happy, but they overcooked my vegan sausage to the point at which it was the texture of jerky.
The beer selection is drool-worthy, but the bathroom situation has GOT to GO.
I wasn't feeling the crowd all that much, but my friends and I managed to grab the couch up front, so at least I didn't have to trip over too many urban outfitters clones during the course of the evening.
Oh, and when I thought the mixed bag couldn't be weird enough, these guys decided to add a DJ. That just seems kinda wrong.

In any case, I'd swing by here on a weeknight for a pint if I'm in the neighborhood, but I think there are definitely better spots to chill and make that one drink turn into several more.
author: Erin P.

description:
While standing at the bar in Gestalt Haus last night, staring at the words "POLISH" and "ITALIAN" scrawled in large, enthusiastic letters on the chalkboard sausage menu, I had a revelation.

No WONDER giving up meat was so painful! I'M half-Polish, half-Italian. I have some serious meat products in my blood. 

Anyway, I digress. Gestalt only offers the Italian in a vegan variety, so that's all I sampled from their grill, but dang, it was good enough. Firm skin on the outside, chewy and juicy on the inside... JUST LIKE REAL MEAT, I SWEAR! Mm mm...

Now, liters of beer, on the other hand... Nobody needs a liter of beer. By the time you get halfway through it, it's warm and flat anyway, and your hand is starting to cramp up from hoisting that gigantic heavy mug (at least it is if you're a wussy herbivore girl like me). But it's a good value, and it's very generous of them to offer it in that quantity.

The bartenders here are also super cool. Very chill, very friendly and generous. If you're into the whole hipster-fixed-gear-revolution-look-thingy, then you'll probably also find them pretty sex-ay.

It's too bad they're in the same neighborhood as Zeitgeist. On a nice day, I feel like a bad person sitting in a dark box with animal parts on the wall when I could be out in the sunshine. Even if they do have vegan sausage...
author: Lisa T.

description:
So I've been walking around the past couple of days with a sore hand - that place between your thumb and first finger, ya know? Since that crazy yelp happy hour at Gestalt Haus the other night ended with some crazy drunken sliding at the Seward Street Slides I kinda thought I'd injured myself there somehow. 

The it occurred to me the sore area was right where the handle rested of that incredibly HEAVY beer glass I was holding all night.
