I had one... okay, one and a half... liter beers at Gestalt and I was pickled. That was a huge beer, in a heavy glass with an alcohol content of 8.something percent - whoa doggy.

Have to admit, I live around the corner and while I was excited to see it opening (who doesn't love a good beer and sausage joint?) I've never patronized the place til now. While I did enjoy myself thoroughly - that potent and ginormous beer made sure of that, along with all the fabulous new yelper friends - not sure I'll make it a regular rotation. Will have to check it out on a non-yelp night to see what kind of regular vibe it has.
author: margot b.

description:
Sausages and potato salad were tasty, filling, borderline authentic and affordable, which is exactly what I needed when I stumbled in... I mean sauntered in last night.  Definitely tops most bar food in this city in all categories but variety.  The beer selection made up for any qualms I might have had about diversity in selection though.  I got to order a couple of brews that I haven't seen since I lived in Austria, and I love that you can order beer by the mass. 

The bartender had a little hissy fit when i gingerly tossed my empty sausage tray on the bar, because he thought I threw it at him.  Odd, since I was only two feet back from the bar, where it landed, and it stayed on the bar. It was a pretty good shot actually, but maybe this guy has a childhood lunchroom trauma that is still haunting him.  I won't judge.
author: Quinn S.

description:
Gestalt Haus is burning up! No really, it's like a bazzillion degrees in this mo'fo. Boys were taking off their clothes, people were sliding off their seats, and those little twinkle lights were starting look hazy through the steam.

I can't tell you if these were a result of the heat or the $9 liters that were consumed en masse (the bar ran out of glasses, people please), but I can tell you that I'd do it again in a heartbeat.
author: Laura D.

description:
This bar gives The Broken Record a run for it's money when talking about excellent sausage and beer knowledge.
It's a fixed gear hangout - so be ready for that.
As long as you can hang talking with very young men who act like they've been around since the stone ages and have the knowledge (google) to back it up, and women who's default expression is as snotty as Angela in American Beauty  - this place will amaze every time.
I love their steins and they have a wide selection of beer (not Toranados, but what is?)
I do wish that the layout wasn't so cramped around the bar area though - as I've said over and over again throughout, I really dislike being cramped. I do understand though that I'm in San Francisco.
SO for some reason, I like this bar a full three stars more than it's competitor across the street, Killowatt despite the crowd.
Maybe I'm just getting easy in my old age.....
author: Theo R.

description:
So I'm on this email list that announces a different bar to check out every Tuesday.  For this week I suggested this place, and the announcement was sent out.  What followed was a barrage of attacks on the owner for scrapping Cafe La Onda and putting up Gestalt in its place.  And before I knew it, the group rendezvous was changed to another bar to appease the complainers!  I hope I don't find people on Yelp trying to pull the same "don't go here" stunt in retaliation for the loss of their coffeeshop.  (or am I too late?)  My roommates and I came here regardless, and I instantly fell in love.  To those who complain, let me ask you something:

1. How many coffeeshops are open the same hours as Cafe La Onda in the Mission?  (answer: 500,000)

2. How many sausage places are open til 2AM in the mission?  Better yet, how many eating/drinking spots have indoor bike racks?

And it's getting better.  Murphy's in the process of setting up a cold room in the back so he can get 8 more taps, all belgian beer.  I'll see you there.
author: Rego S.

description: Gestalt is what it is... a freakin awesome place to go with a buddy to have great beer, maybe a sausage or two, and play BIG BUCK HUNTER all night long! Do not come here expecting to see hot sorority girls. Do not come here to be seen in the latest fashion. Come here to grab a mug of spaten, scarf down a brat, and shoot those BUCKS!!! (They have the World version, which includes BOTH SAFARI and PRO!!) This is a relatively inexpensive place to have an EXTREME amount of fun without douchebags hanging around. The 90s hip hop spinning was a nice touch.
author: Siao W.

description:
Gestalt is basically an art term, you will know about it, and study it, and fucking learn to hate the word if you go to art school. Ask anyone wearing black standing on the side of New Montgomery.

There is nothing Gestalt about this place. Maybe if you get incredibly drunk you can make somethign out.

I like German beer, and wish I knew more German words, and I watch tons of films dealing with the Holocaust, yeah, did you ever watch "The Great Dictator" with Chaplin making Hitler look so funny...? Watch it.

The only thing that bothered me about this place was the strong smell of cheap burnt oil they use for cooking. 

I don't really have much else to say. Thus the unrelated blabbing.
author: Alexia R.

description:
Lately, it's been all about good conversations and finding the places to have them with friends.  

I came with a few friends to Gestalt Haus early after work one evening and we ordered the Hofbrau on the friendly bartender's recommendation.  Price was right, and taste was better than Stella...so we grabbed the comfy armchairs by the window, thinking an hour or two of catching up.  

Before we knew it, we had whiled the evening from 5:30 to past 10.  It happened in the blink of an eye; I swear there was a time warp.  How did it happen: was it in the discussion of our favorite dreams, or the different ways we read books (a couple of us visually, me by sensation and emotions), the ways we remember our past, our left-right brain orientation, the ways in which men might be different than women...yes, there was plenty of bs...lots of the geeky exciting making up bs with some real knowledge which I remember making college days so heady...and maybe that's how there was a time warp.  It's been a long while since those college days, but weren't they exciting?  And isn't it nice to have even better conversations with more knowledge, more experience, and good friends?

Most of the stars are for the conversation and for the friends...I appreciate them: who they are, their vivacity, wits and goodness.  Well, the friends deserve 5 stars...or maybe they are beyond rating.  Or as with all good moments, it doesn't need rating so much as remembering. 

Gestalt: well priced Hofbrau, friendly bartender.  But they really need to do something about the bathroom.  The crowd is the biking crowd in their assortment of disheveled clothes and bikes.  At one point, one of my friends really was thinking of getting a bratwurst, but she got lost again in the conversation.  Oh well, maybe we will get our heads out of the clouds long enough next time to order one.
author: Sooj O.

description:
i love sitting at the bar in the window.

EDIT- I used to, until the last time I went in, the douchy hipster bartender wouldn't serve me because he was busy having the world's most boring conversation with some other loser.
author: steven w.

description:
Wandered by here while looking for another bar. We were already hungry and when we poked our heads in and saw sausages and beer we're like, "Who needs other bars when there's sausages and beer here?" I know that some people feel that Gestalt should offer more than sausages and beer and a couple pool tables, but c'mon you're in the Mission, there's another bar, like 20 feet away. I like places that don't overwhelm me with choice. You can have a sausage. You can have a beer. You can have both, or just one. 

I was trying to keep myself from getting shitty right away so I didn't have the liter o'beer, but MAN is that tempting. I want to come back here some lazy slightly sunny afternoon when I don't have anything else to do and sit down with a brat and a liter and just watch the world go by.
author: Pumpkin K.

description: Clean & well decorated - Check, Pool Table - Check, Plenty of places to pull on your beer & watch the Giants game - Check.. Well, I'm no Giants fan but its typical for almost every bar in SF to be playing nothing but Giants games. I guess directTV just hasnt hit the bay yet. However, of all the places ive been in the bay, this one time the bar tender actually agreed to put the Dodger game on. WHAT?! Also, he even struck up a conversation letting me know he too was a Blue Wrecking Crew fan. So here I am comfortably seated at the bar, crisp beer in hand chatting it up with the service and watching the game. When you take a gander at there tap selection, Its pretty impressive and offer plenty of delicious rarities. The food is also prepared behind the bar and let me tell you, Its ranked high on my list. The ingredients are fresh and the sandwiches sure sit well with my stomach. They have nifty names for there specialty sandwiches as well, I always get a little kick out of specialty titles. All & all, Good food, good beer, good service & the bar tender even covered a couple drinks on the house. Can it get better then that? The answer is yes, It can. The next time im up north, Ill be slipping back in here for some superb eats and fine suds. Now thats what I call, 8 ball corner pocket.
author: Keith D.

description:
Cheap Stella and bratwurst, what else could you want in a bar?

After maneuvering our way out of the overcrowded and annoying Double Dutch on Sat. night, H. led us to Gestalt, which was just what we needed.  Friendly bartenders (who gave me a pint on the house for my bday!) and awesome cheap bratwursts cooked right behind the bar!  

A great place to hang out with friends: a pool table, a bicycle rack, and beer.  Warning:  don't finish the liter if you're already drunk when you get there (Hear that H?!)
author: Annie C.

description:
Gestalt has good beer, nice sausage, perfect location, is totally relaxed about bringing in food from other joints, fun music, an indoor place to park my bike where crackheads are slightly less likely to pee on it, and is pretty comfortable and full of nice people.

But it kind of sucks, and I can't figure out why. It's like they're kind of trying to be Toronado and kind of trying to be Zeitgeist and they succeeded with neither.
author: jason l.

description:
It's hard for me to write accurately about a place I tend to only go to after I'm already half in the bag, but I can happily report Gestalt Haus helps me get completely in the bag.

With a liter of beer I am a happy man. I am even happier that the selection of beers is hearty and, dare I say, manly. Though I don't frequent the Mission much simply because it is not the most convenient commute, I could see myself coming here often.

I could also see myself waking up many a morning and asking "How did I get home? Why are my pants on backwards? Did I get jacked by Kris Kross?"
author: Keith M.

description:
Rule #1: Never drink, eat or enter a bar that has a bike rack INSIDE.

Rule # 2: If more than three people in the bar have a handle bar mustache, are wearing plaid and have a huge back pack on, turn around and leave.

Rule # 3: If you can only drink beer or wine and the bartenders have more attitude than the hipster doushe bags that are staring you down, start swinging.


I wanted to give this place the benefit of the doubt but then I remembered that i was on 16th and Valencia. Fucking douchbaggery at its best. Do yourself a favor, walk across the street to the Kilowatt. At least the doush bags can't bring their doush bikes inside.
author: Go Cat Go G.

description: Do you like bratwurst piled high with sauerkraut? Do you like big ass mugs of beer (good beer)? Do you ever wish that bars devoted a whole wall to fancy bike racks? OK, the last part is not as important. But it is all part of the Gestalt haus experience. In the heart of the Mission, across from Killowatt, this bar has the right mix of grungy hipster with laid back sausage eatin and beer drinkin. I especially loved it when the Rage and Cult was interrupted by the chick who put on some footloose type song and literally did the dance from the movie. No one even batted an eye, so i think it's a chill place for anyone. Thumbs up.
author: Caitlin D.

description:
If you like cheap knock offs of quality bars that have existed in SF for over a decade, then by all means, have a drink at Gestalt. If you like feeling like the bastard child of Toronado, Rosamunde & Zeitgeist, then you'll get a kick out of Gestalt. 

But if you don't appreciate a rude New York owner treating the Mission and your hometown (and who said, I quote, "I'm glad I'm not from San Francisco!") like it's any old Cash Cow, then boycott this Disney-fake attempt at "indie." 

Although I don't need to tell you to boycott. Judging by the mere handful of people there about midnight on a Saturday, the sausages cooked on what looked like a George Foreman grill, and the lackluster beers - Trumer! And Fat Tire! It doesn't get more craft than that - this is looking more tired than I do after a hop-fueled bender.
author: Autumn W.

description:
I like to learn. 
Last night I did some real good learnin.
I now know that when I have to use two hands to pick up my beverage that it is too large for me and I should not be drinking it.
I also learned that when the man says it will take 20 minutes for my sausage to be ready, he means 1 hour and I should not ask him again. 
If my brain was not atrophied by the regular abuse of alcohol I would have absorbed lesson 1 in quick order so that when lesson 2 became apparent I would not have already consumed 1.5 liters of beer. 
Unfortunately the fact that I cannot learn lesson 1 fast enough leaves me doomed to repeat my improper actions in a vicious round robin of I drink too much so I am dumb, I am dumb so I drink too much. 
End of night tally: Approx 3 Liters of beer consumed.
author: Melissa H.

description: They have cider and a pool table. I'm good, son. Is this a dive? If you have to ask yourself, I think not. Chill people there, at least on Tuesday. Bartender (guy) was friendly and was admirably graceful in dealing with harmless riff raff that trolled in.  Carry-on...
author: Brian S.

description:
Dear Gestalt Haus,

Guten tag! I do believe I quite enjoyed my last visit to you. You opened your home to us Yelpers in a way that made us all feel relaxed and welcome. However, next time I come back and decide to have a liter or more of your beer (especially that 9% alcohol devil's brew), please remind me to eat more than a bowl of soup and a sausage the whole day (but you are so considerate to know of my love of sausage - I especially like the chicken-spinach-feta and chicken-turkey-roasted-red peppers. Though I do wish  they were not so dry and that you'd have more condiments like at Rosamunde's http://www.yelp.com/biz/g9LSMqUK5dkUcmpgTnU-dQ?hrid=4qlbjMb0YrEQxZEYI-51vQ).  Also, please discourage me from going to the gym beforehand and exacerbating my dehydration. I believe you will find these precautions to be mutually beneficial to us. 

I would love to come back to visit you, play a little pool, pick a few songs from the jukebox, chat with friends...but I would also prefer to remember these moments for posterity. Til we meet again under more auspicious circumstances.

Best,
Steph
author: Steph P.

description: This place has amazing service and amazing pretzel buns. It could use more seating and a bigger bathroom but it's a quality establishment as is.
author: Michael G.

description:
Hmm, they sell beer by the liter, and pair it with several varieties of hot juicy tube steak?

God should have saved this place for heaven.
author: Rocco B.

description:
I've been hearing about Gestalt over the past months from my biker buddies. So while down in the Mission yesterday I decided to check it out with a few friends. 

I can now confirm why all my bike messenger friends have been crowing about Gestalt. The bar is built for bike messengers, with a bike rack in the bar, a pool table up front, plenty of beer on tap, sausages a plenty, and a great jukebox. You can get beer in three sizes pint, half liter and liter. Just like Germany, with a bike rack.
author: Phil M.

description:
If you like beer as much as I do, this is the only place you should come if you can't get into Zeitgeist or any other bars around the mission. You don't wanna go to Medjool, because it just sucks and they charge a cover. You don't want to go to Blondie's because of all the hoochies. You don't want to go Elbo Room, because it's way too pack and you can't talk with anyone because of the noise and the place smells like piss. 

Last resort. Gestalt. This place is for anyone who don't like large crowds and like to drink beer. They had THE LITTER for $9 dollars, 1/2 liters for 7 and pints for 5. They also got hot dogs if you are hungry. A nice pool table and bike racks for anyone riding their bikes. My only complaint would be the bathroom.
author: Stanley K.

description:
Sadly, I've walked by this place a thousand times and never noticed it, because this is a dive worth checking out.

Great draft beer selection in a wide variety of sized glasses, including the manly-man liter.  Some very nice hard-to-find dark and German stuff on tap too.

They got eclectic sausages (Andouille, lamb, Hawaiian, etc.) that are electric grilled right behind the bar so they are served nice and hot, with kraut, but no onions. They are only $5, but are not very good quality. The buns are approximately two and half times too big -- I guess the assumption is that the bike messengers are famished.

Big pool table front and center (not for the timid or sucky) with room to play. Soccer on the tube.

Very good CD jukebox with one of the bartenders taking over the DJ booth later in the evening. Heard some great all-vinyl funk music here.

A gazillion times cooler than the yuppier-than-thou "The Monk's Kettle" next door.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Gestalt rocks.

Oddly enough, it's an aptly named venue. Take it apart and it's a shoebox-shaped room with a pool table, a long bar, small tables, and, of course, the industrial-sized bike rack that takes pride of place besides the entrance. It offers a good selection of German beers on tap and a small assortment of wursts, including a vegan option. Alas, when we were there, they were out of the potato salad, although I was warned it's meat-laden. Damn.

Beer, bikes & brats---what's not to love? Put it all together, and it can add up to one of the best night's out in the city---ever.

The unpretentious crowd, the friendly staff, the generous pitchers of beer, the chill atmosphere. 

We likes. If they threw in nightly screenings of major international (cycling) tours, I fear we'd never leave.
author: Astrid X.

description:
I can count on one hand the number of times that I have blacked out from drinking. Either I don't drink heavily enough or I just don't black out easily (although details sometimes get fuzzy, I rarely lose a whole evening). Of these few jewels in my alcoholic crown there has been only one that was caused by beer only and it happened at Gestalt.

I fucking love this place. 

It's not usually crowded and they sell liters (yes, LITERS) of beer, which save you both money and time (although if you're out boozing it up in the city you probably have enough of both... it's a nice situation all the same). This makes for an amazing place to bring a few friends and shoot the shit. There's a pool table and a jukebox that has good music in it. They even sell sausages which easily dispatch any drunk-munchies you may have. 

Stellar. 5 stars, hands down.
author: Jonathan A.

description:
I don't know if I will ever try to vegan kielbasa. But I do like knowing that it exists and that if I wanted to I could come here and get it.

Not a bad place to start out the night. But before long the place is packed to the gills and doesn't stand out any more than any other Mission bar.
author: Sharon T.

description:
I haven't been there in a while, but I have some very bittersweet, yet fond memories of Gestalt from back when I used to go there more often, so that probably colors my opinion about it.  I wasn't living in the city yet at that point but had begun spending a lot of time up here recently, and the place struck me as one of the most laid-back, least pretentious bars I'd been in in a while (interesting, because we'd just come from Elixir up the street, which also holds that distinction).

Generally, there are around ten or twelve beers on tap (or something like that; I haven't been there recently enough to sweat to that number), usually with a few local microbrews or something else interesting and unique.  Strictly speaking, I feel like they tend to have more Belgians there than they statistically should, but since I love Belgians, that's just fine by me.  The bartenders are friendly, knowledgeable about their beer, and always happy to make a recommendation or let you try a taste of something before you order a pint.

The other great thing about Gestalt is the sausage.  Now, it's no Rosamunde's, but given that when I've been there I've usually always had a lot to drink or am in the middle of or on my way to having a lot to drink, when I've had them, the sausages have always tasted heavenly.  I'm a big fan of the andouille and chicken (I feel like it was apple-chicken, or spinach-chicken, or feta-chicken, but again, it's been too long to be sure).
author: Angela B.

description:
The bar with a name I can't remember cause I don't know what it means.  I still like it a lot.

They have liter size mugs for $8.  The same one I got at SF's Octoberfest for $15 (not including the mug).  The jukebox is a mix of classic rock, punk and new alt bands.  The bartenders are super friendly, which should make this place real popular very soon.

Haven't tried the weiners yet, but I plan on making this an early evening weekday hang out.
author: J S.

description:
Great little beer & brat house filled with standard-issue Mission hipsters on bicycles.  Lots of long wooden tables to crowd around and sing.  Tasty sausages (vegan even!) grilled-to-order.  

I'd stay away from the liter beers and go with the half-liters instead.  You'll appreciate being able to refresh more often with a nice cold beer!
author: Sugam J.

description:
Sometimes a restaurant or bar is so intentionally lo-fi it's charming. Other times, it just seems lo-effort, or lo-concept. This place had the faint smell of desperation, pleading to be loved as hip and unique despite the fact that it looked like your stoned buddy redecorated your basement while you were out grocery shopping. Even the glazed eyes of the mounted ungulate heads on the wall had the same look of breathless anticipation: "Will they notice this room took fifteen minutes to plan and build? Ba-a-a-a!"

That smell could also have been the brats, although to be frank (ha!) there was a dude *right outside* selling sausages out of a cart that smelled way better. Score one for the well-placed street vendor.

A couple things I dug: One, Prohibition Ale. The Speakeasy Brewery rules, and they're local. Two, the jukebox. Did I just hear Mouthful of Cavities? So somebody else owns that album? Awesome.

The bike rack up front was impressive, actually sort of a showcase inside the bar. The rest of it -- good music and beer, and a lot of seemingly happy people, but not much else to crow about.

If you're a German hunter who rides a bike -- welcome home.
author: andy d.

description:
Place smelled like old sausages (which my friend thought smelled like dog food), beer was so so/kinda warm, jackass bike messenger dude who have their jeans perma-rolled were heckling us as we played pool, and to top it all off there was a roach chillin' next to me...

burly.... not returning unless the last remaining keg of beer in all of the mission was there....
author: kevin w.

description:
Was just chatting with one of the co-owners yesterday at the Pilarcitos 'cross race and realized I'd never done a review of Gestalt, despite having spent quite a few drunk'n nites there both sampling delicious Belgian style ales, german beers(of course) and munching on German potato salad and tasty Brats!

Admittedly, although I am a cyclist (road, mountain and 'cross) I avoided going into Gestalt because I kinduv expected it to be a hipster\trendy bar for all the mission fixie riders ( not that there's anything wrong with that).  So I never popped in there. Turns out it's way mellower than that. I guess all the "hardcore" hipsters go to Zeitgeist ;-)

In any case,  a friend of mine met Murphy at a mountain bike race about 1 year ago and said friend who lives in the mission (actually about 2 blocks away) took me there. I've been sold since!

Where to begin....the bartenders are always interesting, friendly and social. They have full-on bike store bicycle racks to stash your bikes inside the bar! The beer selection is frick'n awesome! From bottled Belgians to Belgian style local micro-brews on tap, as well as a healthy selection of German brews(duh!). And they have various sausages(with german mustard and kraut of course) and excellent German potato salad (with bacon...yum) to munch on as well.

I can't recall a nite when I didn't walk out of there completely blitzed! Those liter double IPAs(10%) will sneak up on you. If you don't remember anything else about this post just remember, you cannot drink a 10% beer, even a pint, like a regular beer without getting tossed purty quickly!

There's also talk of a beer garden! So while it maybe a bit too late for this year as winter is coming....at least you got something to look forward to!
author: isaias J.

description:
I swear we wandered the Mission looking for a place to drink for an hour and a half. Finally fed up I called my girl who lives in the neighborhood and she recommended this place based on "I need a dive for beers in the Mission" By the time we walked from Capp and 23rd we were sooooooooo thirsty and we're relieved to find it finally. 

The place was pretty awesome. Very rustic with antlers hanging all over the walls. Tons of beers on tap. The place was packed with nowhere to sit. A great cast of characters to enjoy and Bob Marley on the box. Would have stayed there all day if I had the chance. Check it out.
author: Cheeks L.

description: they specialize in sausages and beer! yay! it was a random night, my friends and i were suppose to bar hop in the mission but we ended up staying here the whole night. its a really chill place with a massive selection of beer. i forgot which one i tried but its equivalent to a blue moon, which i love! prices were definitely reasonable, $5 a beer. i didn't try the sausages so i can't comment on that. definitely would come back here to try more beer.
author: Stella J.

description:
So let's say you've spent several hours on a bike ride in S.F. and end up in the Mission District and suddenly you have a hankering for some good beer and German sausage at a gritty establishment with a Germanic name so you can refresh yourself and soak up some of the local flavor, but you decide to go to the Zeitgeist at peak time where you find:
-a twenty minute wait for the bar because fifty schmucks ahead of you each decided to order time consuming Bloody Marys
-no more space for your bicycle on the rack outside
-the kitchen has stopped taking orders becaue the kitchen is an hour behind on the previous ones

Maybe you should contemplate riding another three blocks on Valencia Street and going to Gestalt Haus instead.  Their bike rack is indoors, too, for a little extra security.  Plus, this place has no pretense from the staff or the decor of trying to project a tougher image than it actually is.
author: Rick E.

description:
Popped in at 7pm before the medium crowd showed up around 8:30pm on a Wednesday 

19 taps.  Good range of beers.  Murphy's here, not Guiness.  Belgians if you don't like bitter.  German if you must have German.  Hoppiest thing is Big Daddy from Speakeasy.  $4 pints, $5 1/2 liters.  $5 specialty sausages are good but expensive.  Nice bar, several tables, a few ancient couches, and a pool table.  Bike rack out front is scary, but inside it's pretty inviting.  People inside were friendly but not intrusive.  Bartender was normal (no attitude).  Restroom wasn't that gross when I went, although there is writing from floor to ceiling from past customers -- it reminds me of movies where the cops enter the serial killer's hideout, and it's covered in bloody schizophrenic scrawl.  

Overall:  a good selection of inexpensive quality beer... in a dingy environment.
author: Steve C.

description: This place has a lot of great beers on tap. The atmosphere is laid back and pretty dive-y. My only complaint is that the bartender had a cast on his arm, wrapped in an ace bandage. He was handling food with said hand/arm. I don't think I will ever eat here, but I will be back for a beer!
author: P K.

description:
Two words: Not impressed.

We decided to check out what La Onda had become. Walked in enthusiastic, oohing over the cool bikes parked in the corner (nice touch), and then proceeded to the bar.

I tried to greet the guy at the bar several times. Nothing. He was busy talking to his buddy, which did give us time to peruse the paltry menu. Again: Not impressed. I might've liked the beer, but we didn't really get the chance.

They were out of potato salad, one of the few side dishes. The cold shoulder was continuing. "Want to go somewhere else?" Adam asked. We did.

Honestly, there was no post-La Onda prejudice. However, it's sad to see that they've turned one of my favorite cafes ever into some shitty hipster attitude-ridden place. I won't be back.
author: Allison L.

description:
Friendly staff and ok sausage, what more could a girl ask for? I've not imbibed here as I do enough of that across the street. Though this corridor of the Mission is now seriously screwed on java, it's at least got some better food options now. (But don't get me started on the loss of Kelly's)

Went back to try again, it was after an Alley Cat race...yikes! Bikes! Sausage not cooked fresh on premises, a bit bland and sad.
author: Colleen B.

description:
Things you can do at Gestalt: lock you bike inside, drink liters of beer, play pool, drink pints of beer, pee, drink more beer, eat sausages, pee some more, listen to music on the jukebox, drink more beer.  I don't really need more from a bar, but apparently other people do.  

Also note that it's really a bar in the making since the owner has stuff planned for it.  Decorations, however, are probably not at the top of the list.  If you can't drink in a bar that lacks plastic chandeliers and red velour seats you should probably not drink here.
author: Jess H.

description:
A friend met us here, and was witness to some fellatio in front of a church (for godsakes...HA!) after he parked his ride. I immediately railed him for not beating on their window and shaking the whole car in support. I mean seriously people, if you're gonna do the zucchini slick shizam in the middle of Dolores St., you should expect the same. This provided a pretty fantastic starter story for a pretty fantastic starter bar.

Totally cheap, and not nearly as crowded as many of the other bars on this corridor. Really nice tap selection of both German and local stuff - they've got like all of the speakeasy brews (which are all super dangerous), but also have several Paulauner varieties. Awesome that they offer sausage...its like Rosamunde + Toronado had a bastard devil child and this was it! 

Major bonus points for offering beer in 1L mugs. I really really wanted to get one/several, but I think I would have been too tempted to start singing german songs and dancing on table tops. Generally, this wouldn't have stopped me, but I didn't want to make out with the pavement with a bouncer being my wingman. Maybe next time I head back...
author: Sean C.

description:
I likee. I get to come here and hang and have a tall, tall beer for 4 dolla AND I take notes for my holloween costume to come(Hipster chick!) tight denim, check. Jackie O glasses, check. Big 80's belt, check. an oversized goodwill purse, check. And the piece de resistance, a track bike . I used to loath hipsters and I enjoy making fun of them because I know it's incredibly difficult being so hip and 20 something. But then I saw myself in them, and now I just wanna make fun of them all the time!

All this aside, This place has bratworst and potatoe salad for munchees and a pool table -and a place for indoor bike parking, oh course.
author: Cristian M.

description:
There are 3 things you need to know about Gestalt:

1) They serve liters of beer (approx. 2 1/2 pints) in steins for $8. And they have good, interesting beers. Can't beat that with a bat.

2) They have a decent variety of sausages (meat and vegan) for $4.50. Unfortunately they don't have the lovely variety of toppings offered by my beloved World Sausage (RIP) but they're liberal with the kraut and you can add as much mustard as you want.

Taken together, it might be the best way to spend $12.50 on 16th Street.

So why only three stars? 

3) The pool table. It's got to go. The place doesn't have a lot of seating, and the table is taking up a lot of space, and further encroaches on the other space around it. Because of this, it may not be crowded at Gestalt but you won't have anywhere to sit or stand and rest your brat and stein, so you'll have to keep moving. Sad.

Ditch the quarter pool, bring in a few more tables -- it'll be aces.
author: Ian H.

description:
We found our way here after seeking out a place to watch a soccerr match between Barcelona and Manchester United. Our initial bar of choice was unberably packed and in no way would my tall stature of a whole 4'11" be able to see the game let alone the bar to grab a drink!
But alas, we walked up 16th and heard a roar. Curiosity got the best of me and I peeked inside to see the game on several TVs and a large projector screen. Goooooooooal! 
Ventured past the pool table to the bar and ordered two beers. Although there was a decent amount of people, we were able to stand on the side and watch the rest of the game with excitement. After the game we stayed a while for more drinks and it was good to know they served up some snacks. I was bummed that they do not server liquor, but their beer selectiong was decent. They also have free bar parking in the back. Although I wouldn't be crazy about bumping into someone as they tried to manuver their bike through the crowd. There's only one bathroom which was a minus for me. Other than that, it's a dive bar by any other standard. I'll come back here to have some pints and a game next time. Or maybe just sit by the window play some pool with some friends.
author: Dee D.

description: Nice place to grab beer and lounge. There are lots of seating places and some couches. They have boots which i think are fun to drink with friends. There's also a pool table but gotta get there early to claim the table! This place is a little loud and i had a hard time figuring out what ppl were saying unless they yelled at me and i had to yell at them.
author: Liwei Y.

description:
The running joke between Murphy and me was that I would write a Yelp review once Gestalt got more taps, which were on their way. For a month or two, it would be me coming in, handshakes all around, asking what new predicament prevented the kegs from being installed, then offering a reflection on the difficulties of business before ordering a beer larger than my cat. Well, the kegs were installed this week, and so here we go:

They've not only got every single Prohibition beer on tap (that I know of, anyway -- the brewery is right down the street!), they've got all sorts of exclusive and wacky German beers ("It's like being in Munich again!"), oompah music on the jukebox (it's a secret unlabeled disc, check it out), and even a vegan alternatives for the sausages (the kitchen is open late!). They try to please every single type of person who would conceivably ever walk into a bar, and do so flawlessly.

The best thing about Gestalt is that no one there is much of a jerk or a snob. It's such a revolutionary concept, I know, but the staff is friendly. They like beer; they will recommend you beer if you are uncertain of what to get. They like bikes; they will talk with you about fixing their machines. Even a no pants-rolling guy like me can drop terminology like a fixie-riding speedster. Everyone reflects like a mirror: don't be an ass and they won't be one back. Tip, you bastards.

But for Christ's sake, don't order a liter of IPA if you can't stomach it.
author: Garen T.

description:
Randomly found this place while walking along 16th St. and basically chose this one because it seemed like a chill place with some seats around 7pm on a Saturday night. They have a good beer selection for only $4 a pint! Much cheaper than Monk's $7.25 beer! They served sausages behind the counter that I would probably never try, but I guess if you drank enough, they would be good. There is also a pizza-by-the-slice place next door, which may be a better bet. 

Crowd does seem like local hipsters, which wasn't a big deal to me. I would probably come back, but maybe only for a few drinks, since apparently the bathrooms are an issue. If you are coming don't expect to see a sign on the door. Go off the address, because I swear I didn't see a sign in front.
author: Rachelle T.

description:
If you like the beer, you'll like it here.  Also, if you feel like some late-night sausaging, you'll like it here too (though sometimes the sausaging can take a while, when they're busy).

Great selection of brews, if not enormous, including everything Speakeasy makes (like the double, the porter, and the black, which are too damn hard to find on tap for their deliciousness).  $4-pint, $5-1/2 liter, $8-liter.  Now that's a good deal.  And the sausage is cheap too.
Sure, they clearly employed all the interior decorating skills of a guy with a vat of flat black paint and a bunch of leftover white christmas lights, but at least they funk it up with a bunch of antlers and the occasional deer head.
People say it's bright, and it is.  But you're not going to a beer-hall to hook up; that's what Lone Palm or Dalva are for.  You're going to the beer hall to get seriously batty on some damn good beer.
(-1 star for providing beer in liters, while only providing one bathroom for recycling it afterwards).
author: Don H.

description:
I ordered an Anchor Steam and the bartender (a very precise looking fellow) told me "Why don't you order something we have?" Odd. But I like it when someone is a dick to me.

I had a damn fine Sausage here. Like an ass, I expected Top Dog prices, ordered two, and was unhappy about the price. I was tipsy.

To obtain my attention when these sausages had finished cooking, Bartender threw a napkin at me. 

Went back just to give them another chance, but they didn't have any vegan dogs (my friend required, and had found them lacking even previously).

The bike rack is a bike rack.
author: John F.

description:
I took some out-of-town friend here since we were riding our bikes through the city and really, in the Mission, who wants to leave your bike outside, no matter how many locks you have? The beer selection is good, the double IPA I had was lovely.

The only reason Gestalt doesn't get 5 stars is because the table we were sitting at was being dripped on from above. Not sure if it was the roof, a water pipe, or what, but when it hasn't rained in months, I don't want that sort of stuff in my beer. We moved... and proceeded to laugh at the people who sat there after us.
author: Mr. C.

description:
I am less than impressed.  Besides trying to emulate Zeitgeist, the place just has no personality.  A big empty room with a slapdash furniture arrangement is not the kind of place I want to drink beer, particularly when it took over one of the most interesting cafes in the city.  Also, a tip to the "decorators", if you're going to have a corner of big cushy chairs, an endtable might be nice.  It's annoying to rest one's beer on the floor.

Oh, and the selection of beers on tap is weaksauce.
author: Frankie D.

description:
Proof the third time, or make that fourth or fifth time, is indeed the charm:

0/1 - Monk's Kettle. The house veggie burger and pretzels remain elusive. We weren't waiting 45min.

0/2 - Pork Store. Had no idea they closed so early Sun - Wed. 8:30 diners beware.

0/3 - Phoenix. Walked in, were met with perhaps a hundred drunk Celtic fans, walked out.

0/4 - Little Baobab. Closing early for a private party.

1/5 - Gestalt. $5 for a vegan sausage, $4 for an excellent german beer, unpretentious bartenders wearing shorts, rock music that doesn't irritate, the chill Mission crowd at it's finest.

On a warm summer night where gays are marrying and passionate sports fans are celebrating championships, it was perfect.
author: Jason B.

description:
This place is awesome; it has a lot of personality.

Great selection of beers on tap & the bartenders were super nice.

It's got a great set up - you can set up your bike on the bike rack, and there's a pool table, with benches around it. Dead animal heads adorn the wall.

I came here on Halloween, dressed as a mermaid, and embarrassed myself by attempting to play pool. 
Note to self - never drink and play pool. I nearly whacked some of the audience members on the bench with my pool stick. 
Great crowd, though, as people were patiently waiting for me and my boyfriend to finish this never-ending game.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
So I came in there the other night. BOY has it changed. It used to be this whole biker only kinda digs, but I was surprised how it was still welcoming to the new crowd, but had "hidden" bike racks. I gotta admit, I love the couches now haha. Beer selection is still great, but I wished there was a bit more. Maybe some simple well drinks as well too. That would make it better. Saturday night was fun. DJ was playin some hits (all genre's btw: I'm talking everything from The Sounds to Big Pun.. word up!) 
Def glad I came here to chill!
author: Eric A.

description:
Well im not bike scenester which would probably be the reason why I give it four stars. I walk in without a bike..but I've still enjoyed my time here regardless. 

It's always busy, but I like it because it never gets packed to the point where you feel squished. Great beer selection (pretty large beers), oh gosh and its a sausage fest here....no silly, not the men, they serve DELICIOUS sausage/hot dogs, extra delish if you're drunk (i still don't think that came out right) Anyways you get my point, order em with your beer..its yummy! 

Nice little spot, and if you're a biker you can put your bike on the racks inside...which I thought was a pretty clever idea. I love the animal heads on the wall too. 

Service: Mediocre. Don't have really anything to complain about. Ordered, and waited patiently for my sausage to cook up!

Story: One time I went there, my friend got into an argument, and almost a fight.. with a pirate. YES a pirate, a man who thought he was a pirate. lol  We asked him if he came in his ship, which we pointed to his bike...apparently he was offended...relax buddy it was a joke. 

anyways..enjoyed my time here with friends and will return again.
author: Catherine O.

description:
No self-respecting biker/yelper's resume would complete without a Gestalt review. 
A haven for bicyclists and beer
No outdoor seating like Zeitgeist (and subsequent clouds of smoke), but there is an indoor bike rack.
Cleanliness? well let's just say that it's good that they keep it dark.
Lotsa track bike hipsters (which are the new try-to-fit-in guidos btw) who have a fixie as part of a fashion accessory.
A few cocky beyotches with white pants and matching MTV-Kennedy-esque glasses (think they are too cool 4 skool).
If you're riding about town and want to grab a brew and bratwurst, go here, it's a no brainer.
author: G K.

description:
Warm Beer + Cold Shoulders = Never going to Gestalt again.  

I heard about the new "biker" bar replacing one of my favorite cafe's, and wondered if the Mission really needed another venue for alcohol consumption.  This weekend, I got my answer:  not really, or at least not them.  It was hot, I wanted a beer, and instead I got a lot of attitude.  

Maybe an off day?  Maybe I was mistaken?  The world may never know.
author: louda l.

description:
unpretencious goodness. Plentiful and *intentional* indoor bike parking. Great beer on tap. Friendly staff!

5 stars!

(haters without bikes should stay home or go drink at the torranado)
author: A R.

description:
ummm- beer--- Weiss beer--- on tap.  This is a very very good thing. 

4 stars because their bratwurst is actually not bratwurst, it's weisswurst. and the organic rolls fall apart. But up to 4.5 stars because I actually happen to like weisswurst better than bratwurst. But back down to 4 because this former WI girl who was married into a German Milwaukee brewery family for 10 years is tired of having to argue with Californians about what a real (much less a really good) bratwurst is. 

Rant over- rave to come- love the bike racks, love the beer, love my WEISSWURST. The dead animals remind me of home (hunting country, dont'cha know - half my family talks like Fargo) and out here, decorating with any carcass parts of an animal is a bold choice. Sauerkraut comes from heaven to cover my sausages-- yum.
author: Keri B.

description:
Gestalt features three things: bike racks, beer and sausages.

The beer is plentiful, and served in metric sizes (da!). The sausages are tasty. Service is timely.

Seating, on the other hand, is hard to come by. Definitely don't come with a large group.
author: Paul S.

description:
Huge-ass beers
Tasty sausages
Indoor bike rack for the fixie
One bathroom
Stuffed deer heads mounted on the wall
author: Tim B.

description:
I love reading other people's Yelp! reviews for two primary reasons:

1) To get an idea of what I should write about an establishment 

And...

2) To reaffirm my continuing disdain for the human race

The latter is directed toward people who'll give a place a single star for ludicrous reasons. Consider the following from member Mortimer P. "...Gestalt Haus is no longer the rustic, beer-lover's bicyclist destination it once was. It is now, in fact, a generic, boring, and inappropriately flashy bourgeois hangout". Generic? Maybe in the sense that it's exemplifies a Mission "hipster" bar...but it's THE MISSION dingus! Boring? I was in there lastnight and it was rockin'. Dude, if there is alcohol and women and you're not having a good time, go home, put on your latest Death Cab for Cutie album and proceed to cut yourself until you bleed the ennui from your body. Bourgeois? Sir, I saw not a single member of our society's upper crust there...not a single one. 

Folks, I've always been frank with you...when I'm sober. Gestalt Haus, in my humble opinion, is a chill spot. Like Toronado in the Lower Haight it's strictly a beer bar, but the varieties offered are solid. The crowd can be pretty extreme...that is if you're like your's truly and scruffy, skinny jean clad white kids with questionable hygiene give you nightmares. I like Gestalt...I AM GESTALT, and you can too!
author: Rodney P.

description:
Though I'm not a bike rider or hipster, I like Gestalt. I avoid going here too much because sometimes when I've been drinking I make bad choices. Bad choices like ordering two sausages with onions and extra spicy mustard. 
I haven't done that yet, but I am not an animal!! I can only sit there for so long and watch delicious smelling pork products being consumed by others before I finally crack. I just can't risk it. 
I've never had any problems with service and never seen any health hazards,  but that may just be because it's always dark in there when I'm in there. Heavy beer, but a good selection, and reasonable prices.
author: Leah S.

description:
Editing 08/04/2008

My friends and I used to claim "Gestalt is the best bar in SF!" We'd go there once, twice a week. Meet after work, drink our sorrows away and do it all over again.

But then..... around March they changed ownership. -gasp!-

The new owner came in, **put in a DJ booth**, added lame TVs and hired a douchebag staff. What was once a Tuesday ritual is no longer.

The last time I went in there, the bartender was a douchebag and the crappy DJ was playing terrible music so loud on a Sunday that my friends and I left.

We vowed never to go back and we haven't.

Dear Gestalt from 2006, I want you back, dearly.

-------

This is a my favorite new addition to San Francisco.

Gestalt is exactly the kind of place you go to straight after work for some fine sandwhiches and a drink.  They are serving it up true Munich style (no grilled onions, but who needs them?).  :) 

You can't but help love the bike parking, quarky decor, and the *fine* taxidermy.

The crow seems really friendly.... a nice change from some of the other bars in the neighborhod.

Hooray for Gestalt!
author: Lindsay E.

description:
I've decided to like this place. The bartender here on Saturday nights seems like a pretty nice guy (i.e. no hipster attitude), and he is quick with the service. 

The beers, and I am sure you have heard, can be ordered by either the pint or the liter, and quite frankly, there are not enough bars that serve beer by the liter. Mugs the size of your head = memories of Oktoberfest. I'd like the beer selection to be better, but I happened to have a little chat with one of owners last night, and she assured me that they plan on expanding the selection  soon. I think to 60 beers, is what she said. 

They have a pool table and a decent jukebox. Seating seems a little sparse, though. I swore the last time I was in here, there were a couple of booths, but I may have just been drunk, because there weren't any this time. 

I have yet to try the sausages, but the fact that you can get a bite to eat while drinking and without having to leave the establishment is always  nice. 

I have improved my hipster filter quite a bit recently, so I don't care if there does happen to be dozens of fixed-gear bikes in close proximity, as long as no one makes me ride one.
author: Tom H.

description:
Came here in lieu of Range or Walzwerk because Pepe's plane got in too late from MIA last night.  :( Pretty chill place, definitely like a beer hall --  I liked the white Christmas lights against the black walls, but my bf pointed out that it was really bright inside to be a good ol' hangout bar for him.    

The beers & sausages (I had the Chx Jalapeno. Yum!) were standard, but something was missing (ah yes, hard liquor).  Also I managed to get tangled up in the bikes racks in front of some uber hipsters (wait is this the dream where I'm naked in front of everybody?), which put a little bit of a damper on the start of the evening.
author: Melissa S.

description:
Def better snags than what you'll find at the movie theaters.  Good luck finding a table.  I watched two of my beer-loving friends struggle to get to the bottom of each of their liters of beer.  If you come w/ your bike, don't be surprised if the racks are full.

One downside, no outdoor seating, esp in the summertime.
author: Anonymouse C.

description: Depending on the night of course, this is the only bar in the entire Mission I can stand to be in. This is a good pre-meet up place. The beer selection is ample. The bar tenders a-ok. The music not barf inducing. The people are generally ok.
author: Helena L.

description:
The German qualities of this place go only as far as the name, the beer and that they serve bratwurst. 

The adventure into Gestalt Haus begins.  The pool table is right near the entrance so chances are you'll be waiting for someone to take their turn before actually getting out of the doorway.  After you make it past the players, you are rampaged by people who have turned the empty space before the bar into a cramped dancing area, owing thanks to the loud techno.  Proceed with caution.  After making it through the light gauntlet of elbows from the tables lined along the bar you finally make it towards the back and can breathe easy.

So why bother?  Easy, the beer.  Delicious German beers and most of the Speakeasy brews are available on tap.  All pints are a flat  $4 which is great.  Good attempt to try to make it German by offering beers in half-liters and liters.  Eventually at some point you'll hopefully be able to snag a table and enjoy your beers, making it actually a pretty fun place for a few rounds of "would you rather?"

Someday this place might endear me enough to get a 4, but for now it's a 3 and a solid backup for when Kilowatt is far too crowded.

Oh yeah, is there more than one bathroom in this place?  If not, that is something that should really get taken care of given this place only serves beer.
author: Steven R.

description:
I actually really like this place a lot. It's a good place to go with a small group of friends and hang out.  It's not big so you may have trouble finding a table but I actually prefer to sit at the bar because the drunker I get, the easier it will be for me to procure one of their delicious sausages. This place actually has really, really good sausages! and it's so perfect with the beer.  I ate three sausages in one evening, and thank goodness for that because I suspect they had something to do with the fact that my hangover the next day was not as bad as I thought it would be. 

The one thing is that the sausages kinda take a while to cook, but it is so worth it. And they grill the bun too. I also really like that they have bike racks inside of the bar so you can keep an eye on your ride while boozing.  And as it has been stated before, this place isn't great for meeting chicks because it's mostly dudes that come here. But great for me because they are all hot bike messengers! (sorry to the bf here)
author: Jade L.

description: Stumbled in here last night when we were walking out of delirium. They were playing great music plus it looked like there is actually room to walk around, which is amazing for a bar in the Mission on a Friday night. I didn't realize that it was a beer and wine bar at first so I was a little disappointed when I couldn't order a regular drink. However, the bartender was pretty helpful and helped me pick out a beer that I would like. We were also able to get seats on the couches at the front of the bar. The only downfall for me was the fact that they do not have a full bar. Otherwise, I would definitely recommend this place to others who are looking for a place in the mission where you can easily get to a bar.
author: Kate G.

description:
One of the friendliest, most helpful bartenders in the city! He patiently explained the ordering process, let us sample beer, and then introduced us to the brewer of the suds we selected. And he didn't make fun of us for not bringing in a bike or being in work clothes. What a sweetheart! And I don't even like beer but I love this place. 

This wasn't an anomaly or a bartender having a good night either, I have been here before with different friends and he was the same lovely, patient guy.

Yummy sausages too! I love a Polish, no kraut.
author: Krismet C.

description:
I will preface this review by saying that my recollection of Gestalt House is a little fuzzy, mainly because I was tore up from the floor up.

I don't like beer and I don't like a bathroom that #1 has to be shared with drunk men and #2 has a veritable marsh of overflowing liquid of some sort or other on the floor in front of the toilet (see origins of which are discussed in point #1). Aside from cheap beer which I'm sure drinkers of beer enjoy, the decor is shabby, and they closed the kitchen meaning I couldn't have a drunken Kielbasa (me being the drunken part of that equation).

The bartender had ZERO sense of humor about #1 being asked if we could have a microwaved Kielbasa, #2 being asked if they had anything more than beer or wine and #3 some girl trying to hang something from one of the many pairs of antlers on the wall - a bra? She got shouted at across the bar in a very merry-killing way. The whole bar went silent. I probably would have cried. Dude, it's a crappy bar....with antlers. Lighten. Up.

******Update....10 minutes later**************
After reading more reviews I am compelled to add to my own review. I believe that Mr. McNoSenseofHumor is the owner and I am incensed that he said, "the kitchen is closed" when in fact he really meant "The George Foreman has been unplugged." As a native, I also resent any reference to this place being a "Portland" bar.
author: Eli B.

description:
Well I must say i love this bar super fun bartenders, djs on some nights, maybe a beer pong night in the future we shall see but i love this bar its always my first stop in my evenings maybe if they get a beer pong night with a good dj ill be able to bring a lot more ppl to this bar! overall great bar!!

I love the fact that they have a bike rack thing as well, especially since all of my friends ride bikes its convenient that they have the option of hanging up inside :]
author: Christopher R.

description: Came in around noon after a great bike ride around the city from the morning.  For some reason I desperately wanted a really good pint of ice cold beer.  Bar was empty, and the bartenders were doing prep work for the food at the counter.  I ordered a pint of Spaten and as I sipped my beer with my friend, we kept noticing their hand written sign for their vegan tuna melt.  So we decided to split that since we were hungry.  The bartender gave us an amazing potato salad to go with it.  The sandwich was SO good.  The bread was amazing, and everything was perfectly toasted and melted.  Apparently this sandwich sells out everyday.  So I will be back!  And they have decent facilities too! :)
author: Modern L.

description:
I was a little suspicious of the place at first. Thought it might be a little too hipster heaven. And it's not like we need another bar on this block.

BUT

I completely dig it. They've got a nice selection of beer, which is available in large and even larger mugs. Indoor bike rack (I don't own a bike, and I live less than a block away so I wouldn't ride my bike there, anyway, but I appreciate the fact that they have one). There's a pool table, which makes the hubby happy. And get this: the bartender actually asked me if the place met my expectations. Since when do bartenders, even friendly ones, give a rat's ass about whether or not the bar meets your expectations? I was very impressed.
author: Amy K.

description:
Not a bad bar at all.
I was half expecting it to be full of sneaky-swede faced hipsters in their tight pants and pristine bicycles that they only ride to bars, but there were normal people there. The Polish sausage is enh, but the kraut tastes homeade so I'll try another one next time.

This place is at least 5x better than what was there before (Cafe La Onda or whatever the hell it was called).
author: Tom S.

description:
Even though this place is really close to where I live I never went in until last night.  I think I'd been scared off by what I expected would be a cooler than thou attitude given my experiences with certain Zeitgeist patrons.  
But to my surprise I loved it.  They have lots of great beers, the bartender was really friendly, they have food, and they have wine.  Even Sauvignon Blanc which makes me happy cause so many bars seem to only have chardonnay.  We didn't have to wait for long to order our drinks.  (Perhaps because it was a Tuesday evening, but still, it is nice to be served promptly.)

This space works much better as a bar than it did as a coffee shop.  I'm bummed that Cafe La Onda didn't make it but if it had to go away I'm glad a pleasant place went in to replace it. 

It gets that coveted fifth star simply because the bartender gave me a necklace made of candy for no apparent reason.  Plus I'm a sucker for pretty Christmas lights.  I'll definitely be back.
author: C S.

description:
Dear Gestalt,

I'm sorry.  I'm sorry for all of the rude things I've said and thought about you since Cafe La Onda turned into you.  I silently judged you and avoided you for all these months.

But tonight I learned that you're not just trendy and hipstered out, you're actually pretty rad.  Your bike parking is really great, your German potato salad with bacon is delicious, and your sausages are thick and juicy.  Your bar dude was very nice and not at all pretentious.

But the best part is that you have Krusovice on tap.  And not just regular Krusovice, but cerny Krusovice, too.  You're the only place outside the CZ where I've ever seen dark Czech beer on tap.  And it tasted so good.  It was the perfect temperature and the perfect not-too-creamy, not-too-watery consistency.  I wanted to drink seven pints of it.

I will be back, often.  Probably not at prime time on a Friday or Saturday night, but there are plenty of other hours in the week for us to spend together.

Please accept my apologies, Gestalt.  Thanks for proving me wrong.

Love,
Megan
author: Megan D.

description:
Gestalt has a bunch of good beer for a relatively good price.  The standout afternoon beer place on that stretch of 16th Street between Valencia and Guerrero, it also a good place for a nighttime beer as well.

I have been inappropriately drunk here more than once and it's a great place to be so.  True, they have taken out the bike racks and it's much less of a rowdy bicycle bar than it was in the past, but that's alright--as at any bar, you can still get rowdy if you want.

I haven't tried the food there, but word is that the (inexpensive) sausages are pretty tasty.

Whether you're using it for an afternoon beer meeting or a Saturday Night prequel to Delirium or a bar for the evening, I highly recommend Gestalt Haus. 

And no, Jon.  They don't play Staind and Linkin Park in there.  The juke has a pretty decent selection.
author: Stef A.

description:
Went there last night -- this is my new favorite bar.  $7 liters make a damned good argument. 

Bike parking, cool bartenders, and vegan options on sausages so no-one has to go hungry means it's easily 5 stars. 

Thankfully it's not terribly overcrowded yet -- we were there on a friday and  all the seats were full but you didn't have to push by anyone and the bathroom line was bearable. Go there quick before it's impossible to get a drink!
author: rajan a.

description:
I don't know what all this hateration is for.  I mean, the staff is beyond nice, the food doesn't suck and the beer rocks.  What more can you ask for?  
I've been there every Friday and Saturday for the past few weeks (Gestalt whore?  Yes.) and have had a great time.  It's nice to go to an unpretentious dive bar and actually be treated with respect (ahem, Zeitgest).
And the jukebox totally rules--you can really get the whole bar singing along with you to the jams they have on that thing.  And liter beers?  Come on.  This place is cool.
author: Sarah H.

description:
So I wanted to dislike this place for a number of reasons, but then I actually WENT one evening, and I have to say, despite my desire to not like it, I totally love it. What an awesome local bar. Not a biker, but I like that they're taken care of. Good enough amount of seating for the time being. Delish beers, and often things you don't see elsewhere. Oh, and vegetarian sausage! What's not to love.

My only complaint is that they need another loo. Preferrably one for girls and one for boys. That possible?
author: Jen B.

description:
I went here a few weeks ago. Nice beer selection. Nice bartenders, A little cramped, they only serve beer, from a serving standpoint i really like this. You can buy full liters of beer for 9 bucks. The jukebox is early 90s alternative rock which is a nice change of pace from all the hipster crap out there. 

Overall a pretty nice bar, a little cramped, with a good beer selection

i recommend this place
author: Sean B.

description: Came in for lunch since I desperately needed a good beer to dissolve the stresses of my obnoxious coworkers. Also wanted to take advantage of the 50% scoutmob coupon (essentially $10 credit). Got the vegan tuna melt and my friend had the 16th st club. My sandwich was pretty good, the faux meat was really finely diced with veggies and came with fresh lettuce and onion on swirled rye. I think it had faux cheese because of the strange not-cheesy taste those tend to have (and being a vegan sandwich). The bartender was super friendly and the place was practically empty at 1:30pm. I was kinda bummed because the Scoutmob app said they had adult combos that included beer and sandwich but I didn't see any indication they exist. Seemed a little pricey at $30 for 2 sandwiches and beers (sans coupon, $20 with). I'd like to come back in the evening for vegan sausage and beer.
author: Cori W.

description: Very cool little place. They don't have Guinness but they had two other stouts on tap and the chocolate stout was particularly good. The Sausage Sandwiches for a handful of $$ was also a deal. Eclectic mix of people and inside parking for your bikes? That's just frickin' sweet.
author: Kim N.

description: A 16th Street staple for years. Generally a low key, local crowd and not too packed except sometimes Friday and Saturday nights. Great beer, great sausages and fresh pretzels, and almost always, good music including a rocksteady/reggae DJ on (I think) Friday nights. Also several pinball tables.
author: Jason M.

description:
I could be myself here, I felt, and by being myself I mean, for example, playing bongos on the table with friends (and being joined by a rather good-looking stranger), or writing my name on a napkin with ketchup. The crowd was all right, and I can't help but loving those dirty, dirty Mission boys who could use a shampooing every now and again. I kid, I kid (I love, I love). Bike rack inside is a gem. 

Music was groovy. Bongo-inspiring groovy.
author: Jorge C.

description:
Oh Gestalt........  What are you becoming?  Not a fan of the "improvements" that are going on, and neither are the bartenders.  My friends and I need to find another Thursday night scene.  

It *used* to be a dark, dingy place with deer heads and antlers on the walls. 

Now it's over-lit, with bright red walls and shitty, over-priced art hanging on them.  

If they raise the beer prices, we are officially over, Gestalt.  Consider yourself warned.

Other than that, if you aren't an idiot dick, the bartenders will be very nice to  you.  And if the bartenders *really* like you, they'll put on the shop-from-home sex toy channel instead of soccer.  The snausages are yummy.
author: Kat M.

description:
Caveat - I went just for the food, and to say hi to a friend for her birthday.

I wish the sausage concept was a bit better played out - the bread got soggy due to the huge amounts of sauerkraut on it, so the tastiness of the sausage was minimized. The sausages are healthy and organic and froo froo -- not bad I guess but I wanted some real pig fat in my weiner. The sausage was a bit salty, too...which if I were going to be chugging some beers, they would've made for a nice compliment.

Also the service at the bar was a bit slow tho no one else seemed to be ordering anything. The bartender was nice but he'd had some cell phone chaos happen that nite, so was spending a bit of time focused on that issue....
author: Liz K.

description: I came here with some friends after playing basketball so I was super hungry.  We came here for sandwiches so I thought it was interesting that this place was a bar.  They serve all sorts of different sandwiches with an interesting twist.  I got the Rueben which is corn beef with cheese and sauerkraut.  This is one of the best corn beef sandwiches I have ever eaten.  I could be bias since i love sauerkraut and I usually put a whole lump on my hot dog.  I drenched the sandwich with mustard as well.  This place is great. If I was walking down MIssion next time, I would stop by - have a beer, a sandwich, and watch some sports.
author: Ernesto F.

description: I had fun UNTIL MY IPHONE WAS STOLEN OUT OF MY PURSE. I was here last night (New Years) and when I told the bar tender, he shrugged and said, "thats the second one thats been stolen here tonight." What kind of place is this?! So yes, good beer, but is it worth it?
author: B F.

description:
I pass by Gestalt a lot and finally in the past  month have now been here a few times.

I like their beer selection, but I was really surprised to find out they charge 6 dollars for Radeberger, especially when it is 4.50 across the street at Kilowatt.

They have a decent pool table.

The sausages, are pretty tasty too.

Unfortunately, I did see a bug here when playing pool.  Fucker was heading right towards my beer so I had to crush it with one of those plastic things on the table.  I know they are everywhere but seeing them is the clincher, and other than the pool table, I am not very into this place.

Oh yeah and the bathrooms have this crazy lacquer on the floors where it always looks wet.  Is it wet? I'm not sure.  *rubs foot on possibly wet floor*  Hmm, guess not.  EL BABYGIRL does not like falling.
author: Adam C.

description: laid back and chill in the mornings, not sure about evening or night. The bartender was amazing, knew the beers really well and even gave us one of those little mini beer mug testers. Didn't have the food so I don't know.
author: Katie B.

description:
I came here with a few friends last week to check out this new bar at 16th and Valencia and had a great time. Its pretty much a straight up bar without pretentions. Its got the feel of a European beer hall with cool design that doesn't go over the top trying to be cool and trendy. 

Good selection of beers and sausages. I didn't try one but they looked good and I'll have to get one next time. The staff here was great too. Totally friendly and fast. All around, a good chill spot to get drunk at in the mission.
author: Steve B.

description:
$8 liter beer.  
$4 pint beer.  
Every dive bar should have hot dogs (ok, polish sausage + sauerkraut).16th and Valencia is like dive bar central.  Gestalt's across from Kilowatt.
author: Chris P.

description:
- - - - - -
Update: I finally went in hungry, and ordered a Santa Fe sausage + kraut. It was perfect. Where's that sixth star?
- - - - - -

As a place to go for beer beer beer, this is tops. You can pretty much pick from the taps randomly and be assured of a quality brew. My personal favorite is New Belgium's tasty 1554, but you'd have to try to go wrong with these choices. Sure, the menu's not as massive as Toronado, but the quality of the selections makes this a true beer-lovers' bar.

If you do bike there, it's hard to beat the bike parking-- indoor trays. But you certainly don't need to be a biker to check this place out and enjoy good beer.

Friendly staff, beer served in liter glasses, a decent jukebox, plus all of the above = my new favorite bar.
author: Daniel M.

description:
You know how when you get a printer/scanner/copier, you get an okay printer, a shitty scanner, and a depressingly awful copier? 

To winnie c., who suggested that Gestalt is Toronado plus Rosamunde plus Zeitgeist, I would propose that the sum of these three things turns out to kind of suck.
author: Tim S.

description: Good beer at a good price and they have Big Buck Hunter.  This is a great little dive bar and is never too crowded.  If you're looking for a swanky bar, this is not your place.
author: Jessica J.

description:
I love this bar! the beer is excellent, the hot links are soooo awesome!!

plus all my bike friends are there... shouts to murphy!! thx for the awesome racks!!
author: Benjamin H.

description: Its more of a bike messenger hang out, hole in the wall, I love that they have a pool table. Went inside and I was dressed coming from work so maybe I looked like a corporate hipster to the bartender. We had the a couple of beers and played pool, also had the spicy sausage (Very good and tasty), Would I come back? no, I didn't feel like the bartender wanted me and my friends there although we were very nice and tipped well. I think they feel if you don't have green hair, piercings and grungy looking they don't want you there. My friend asked to use the juke box and the bartender said it was broken, but honestly really seemed that he wanted his Slayer music that he had playing since the bar was pretty empty. I've been to plenty of dive bars and I know how this works and how some bartenders act when its early afternoon and no one is in the bar they want it their way. I am sure others will find this place fitting for them. I love dive bars but was not impressed to come back.
author: X X.

description:
Hmm.  Who doesn't like beer and sausage?  Or maybe beer and bikes?  Gestalt Haus is for you!  

I love the beer selection and the prices are good (read - cheap), it's no frills and I dig that.  There is, however, very limited space and the place is dark, a little dirty, and loud.  Go early so you don't have to stand next to where everyone and their brother is trying to park their cool 10 speed.  (Maybe everyone is riding a bike because there's no effing parking in the Mission.)

Make sure you roll up the legs of your jeans so you'll fit in with the hipster crowd and lock the door to the bathroom so I don't walk in on you.  Yikes!
author: Tempe M.

description:
I went here for a party a bike shop threw.  Nedless to say I was not impressed.  they have some poorly designed bike racks by the front door.  I saw a handful of bikes fall over in the half hour I was there.  The beer selection was sub-par, and they don't serve hard liqour!!  

WHAT IS A BAR WITH NO WHISKY?? 

One star I am giving is for the oversized(pitcher size) mugs of beer you can get. 

The Second star is for the girl at the end of the bar with the broken nose.  You are a trooper to go out with your face all busted up.

I'll give this bar a second chance if I can ever trick anyone into going with me.
author: Joey R.

description:
Huge beer selection on tap + sausages + great bartender = Happy Jessica B.! 

We had the pleasure of going to this place on Tuesday night for a friend's birthday party and I can't wait to go back again.  The scene was pretty quiet when we got there at 8 and there was no problem fitting everyone in.  It had picked up by 10, but you could still walk around at least.    

We drank lots of great beer and ate a couple of sausages piled with sauerkraut and mustard.  The Kielbasa was great, as was the Brocwurst.  I'm strangely interested in trying the vegan sausage now though.  Maybe next time.

And special thanks to the brilliant and hilarious bartender.  It was a pleasure sitting at your bar.  I think your name was Marcus, but you did your job so well that I'm not so sure.  Either way, thank you!
author: Jessica B.

description:
i really like this place.  the vibe there is so great, so friendly.  and one of my favorite combos is a nice brew w/ their vegan sausage w/ saurkraut (don't worry meat eaters - they have other great meaty options!)...mmmm yum.  even tho i don't bike (me and the chihuahua like to have our feet on the ground), i like that they have bike parking INSIDE - good move to move it to the back and expand the seating area in the front where you can people watch inside and out.  and good move to add more tables along the wall.

and the people who work there are really nice, always feel welcome and confortable there.  and BONUS, my pooch is welcome!  yes. y'all - dog-friendly!  any place who welcomes my pooch with open arms is more than ok in my book!  

and it's soooo close to my house, has a pool table, and warm red walls - the kind of red i'd paint my walls if i wasn't such a committment-phobe!
author: Suzanne A.

description: I came here cause I was in the Mission and needed to pee. I stayed because they had Spaten. And the A's game was on and they were kicking ass. 2 Spatens and a Blue Moon later, I'm off. Its a nice environment to have drinks with friends. Not too pretentious, not dressy, just a good old fashion German bar with sausages. Can't complain.
author: Joan S.

description: A friend turned me on to Gestalt- fun, a little divey, all kinds of great German and other beers, sausages and sauerkraut- usually pretty busy- great place to get inexpensive good food and great beer before a show or something in the Mission. I'm always happy when I'm in the neighborhood and going back to eat/drink there.
author: JOHN S.

description:
I thought this was a biker bar but it's more than that.. They have a nice selection of beer and the bartenders are super pleasant. The crowd varies.. Typically bikers, but to my surprise two Saturdays ago it was very Marina.. hard to believe huh! But true...

I love the Mission.. she likes to mix it up
author: Monica S.

description: If you love the sausage & beer dive operations, you'll love Gestalt. Ride in with your fixie, hang it on the wall and enjoy a happy hour chowdown washed down with a cold beer. Stay for a game of pool or maybe a tune on the jukebox. Perfect on a weeknight. What's not to love?
author: Alex H.

description:
$4 pints, good variety, not much space.  Haven't tried the sausages, next time.
Bartenders were okay to our group, no problems, fast service, friendly, but it wasn't super busy when we went.
author: Roni L.

description: Pretty cool bar, bike rack, pool table, beers - what more can you ask for? They even serve snacks here. Went here after noshing a few mexican delights at Pancho Villa on a barhopping spree in the Mission. Crawlers on a budget, that's what I call us. LOL
author: Mika D.

description:
This places is most easily compared to Zeitgeist.  It is full of dudes and chicks that ride fixed-gear bikes all over the city in search of cheap beer and a place to park their bike with a modicum of safety.

Rest your weary legs (you don't have brakes do you?) here my friends and get a pitcher for yourself.
author: Thadd L.

description:
Friendly, open, warm, awesomeness.  This bar is mellow, dark, high ceilings, relax, good juke box, space and chairs to sit.  I was impressed a bar like this exists in the Mission on Saturday. 

Had great time drinking $9 liters of beer with friends, just a warning to be careful with chugging competitions, a liter of beer is no joke.
author: Mary R.

description:
I used to go here all the time- it was my favorite bar!
Good Beer+Sausage+Bicycles=pure happiness

However, they seem to have redecorated. I walked in the other day to find the bike racks gone and i felt sad. I ordered a beer (maybe out of nostalgia) and left as soon as it was done. 

Bringing my bike inside made this place special, now I guess it just felt like a boring old bar in line with all of the others...
author: Emily W.

description:
Gestalt you have a special place in my heart!  
Why (in no particular order)?
1) Liter beers
2) Awesome juke box:  i did the chicken dance
3) Purty bikes
5) Sausages (however i had to take away 1 star because the Polish sausage was terrible)
4) a pool table
5) the night ended in hugs for everyone
author: Stacy F.

description:
